Dear Sir:

We have finished the test for the sample of water which you sent in and find a slight trace of sewage contamination in our test of the 5 cc quantity, but the report was negative in all the smaller quantities. It is possible that there may be some slight seepage into your supply. When plated out in beef extract agar it gave a bacterial count of 6,833 bacteria per cc. This is much higher than is allowable in a good drinking water since the standard for a first-class water calls for a count of 100 bacteria or less. There was also amongst these fairly large number of organisms which liquefy gelatine, and it would act on protein matter in the water if such is present, possibly causing a bad odor if the water has been standing for some time. Outside of these points we did not see anything objectionable.

Maybe by looking into and cleaning source of supply you can improve the quality of your water. There is always danger of typhoid contamination wherever we find a positive sewage test, although this danger arises only in the case of human sewage of typhoid origin. Animal sewage will also give positive test but may not in itself be the cause of human disease.

Yours truly,

[Signature]
Professor of Bacteriology.

This sample of water was taken out of the taps in the School, being part of the regular supply — H.B. Curry.
Birtle, Man. 1 Nov. 1929

Dear Mr. Scott,

I am not sure that you have a very clear idea of the various properties under consideration and their location, so I have prepared a map that I believe to be correct and showing the various properties in which we are interested.

1. The Brown Line - Showing the Provincial Motor Road from Winnipeg to Edmonton, and passing through Birtle.
2. The C.P.Ry. - Winnipeg to Edmonton Rr.
3. The Birdtail Creek, coming into Birtle from the North East, and leaving Birtle South West.
4. Birtle Town, Birtle Station about a mile from the town, and the Indian School between the Birtle town and Station.
5. The present Indian School farm on S.W. ¼ of 16-17-26 Range.
6. Each ½ inch square represents 1 square mile, 640 acres.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6253, File 575-9, part 1)

VERY POOR COPY
7. The Edmonson property (Purple) on Prov. Highway - about 4½ miles from Birtle Station; the Brown Spot shows location of the well.

8. Red - S.W.¼ of 7-17-25° Owned by Fred Butcher and an option taken on same for School Site.

9. Blue - ¾ of 6-17-25° Owned by John Butcher and an option taken on same for School Site.

The only way to get to Birtle Station from the latter two places is via Prov. Motor Road, from Fred Butcher's gate to Birtle Station is 9 miles. Fred Butcher's place about 3½ miles from Solsgirth.

After noting the above you will have a correct idea of the locations.

I have to acknowledge your letter of the 24 Oct., in which you state the water power Dr. Report is before you, re the Edmonson well - one clause of the report "It does not..."
appear to be fed by a flowing spring." Then what is a flowing spring? This well was pumped to within 15 inches of the bottom, and it could not be got lower. At this level, it came in as fast as we pumped it out, rate about 800 gallon per hour. If this is not a spring what does the water power do, call it? It certainly flowed boiling out of the ground, and quite visible.

Now as to being "unfit without treatment," what did you find in the sample of water out of this well, sent in by Mr. Pinkin, Sup't of the Brandon Experimental Farm. When Mr. Gow was here testing Mr. Edmonson's well, there was a couple of "gophers" drowned in the well because of an opening in the platform and Mr. Edmonson is sure other gophers had met a like fate behind the well casing—and any contamination from them can be easily overcome. When Mr. Gow was here he promised...
to send a report to Mr. Edmonson, on the sample of water taken away, this promise was kept, and the report said there was 336 Colin Bacilli, per C.C.

You say the Dept. is hesitant about this water supply - why so? This water is clear as water can be, good to taste, has no bad odor when taken from the well, nor when left standing several days - nor when boiled. For about 15 years the community have used it and with no ill effects. And after all, as we say "the proof of the pudding is in the eating."

The Dept. need not hesitate using this water that tests 336 per C.C. There seems to have been no hesitation letting the School use the present supply - for many years - that tests 6.833 per C.C. (I will enclose you this report.) And even with this 6.833 per C.C., since coming here in May 1927, I have been able to maintain fair health. The health had been bad previous to my coming here.

Mr. Edmonson is not satisfied with Mr. Cow's report and he has sent other samples of water out of this well to two or more places for analysis.
He may have the results by now but I have not heard.

So far as I am concerned, I from the very first, last spring, passed my judgment on the Edmonson place, and I have no reason as yet to change it. I feel my reputation is at stake. Last spring I said the Edmonson place was suitable as a farm and as a school site. I am now in my 20th year in Indian School work, and if after all these years I do not know a suitable place, after a careful examination, well it is time I stepped aside and let a man with better judgment have a try. I do know the work at Alberni was 500 times better when I left than when I took hold of it, and the same change is taking place at Birtle today—Birtle citizens are taking note of the fact. (See Letter from "Board of trade" enclosed.)

The Church authorities have endorsed the Edmonson site. The people of Birtle, in a petition sent you endorsed it. In your last letter 24 Oct., you say "If you learn of a likely looking..."
Birtle, Man.

farm in the meantime, do not hesitate to report to the Dept." I have nothing else to recommend until the Edmonton place is definitely turned down, after that there is 3rd section (marked in green on map enclosed) that might be considered. It is off the main Prov. Motor Road. By touching the corner of this property and a spur for unloading coal might be obtained. Later I may give fuller data.

I have no place yet for my stock and there is about four inches snow. It is cold and blowing hard tonight. I do give them feed but cannot provide protection. The simplest, least expensive protection would be a (board-tar paper roof) and walls of single boards, banked with straw, and should be for at least 10 head of stock—30 feet long and 12 wide. Shiplap lumber is $4.20 to $45.00 a 1000. Material will cost not less than $100.00 and labor extra. Yours faithfully,

H.B. Currie

Dear Sir:-

Re location of the proposed new Indian School at Birtle.

We had your assurance some months ago that this School would be located in the Birtle district, and within a reasonable distance of the Town of Birtle.

Recently, we have intimation that a site on F. C. Butchers farm, Section 7, Twy. 17, Rge. 25 W. is being considered for it. This Section is some seven miles from the Town of Birtle, and we would consider it is out of the district, and would urge that no definite action be taken to acquire it for such Indian School purposes until other locations that are available, and more suitably situated, be given fuller tests for their adaptability for such School.

Yours truly,

EJW/C.

Dear Sir or Madam,

Herewith the result of the examination of the sample of water sent in by you -

Total number of bacteria present per cubic centimeter 72

Bacillus coli present in 6 cubic centimeters

This result indicates that the water should be regarded as belonging to class "A" (see below).

Class "A" - Satisfactory. Fit for all domestic purposes.

Class "B" - Although showing a degree of contamination slightly greater than the standard set for good well water it is probably safe for domestic use.

Class "C" - Not very bad but a possible source of danger. Should not be used unless previously boiled.

Class "D" - Dangerous. Should be condemned.

N.B. - A sample collected during the cold weather when the ground is frozen may appear to be satisfactory although in the summer water from the same well may be very dangerous.

The fee for this examination is two dollars per sample. Cheques should be made payable to the Department of Bacteriology, University of Saskatchewan.

Yours very truly

[signature]

CANADA

November 6th, 1929.

Memorandum,

Mr. Ferrier has asked me for an opinion on the well which is located on the Edmonson property near Bintle, which property it is proposed to purchase for the new Indian Residential School.

It is a most difficult matter to give a worth while opinion on a water supply which one has never seen. The following facts must be considered:

1. Whether the supply is now safe.
2. If not, whether it can be made safe.
3. If so, whether it is liable to become unsafe through circumstances which may readily arise.

The water in this well has been subjected to at least three bacteriological tests, two of which show that the samples taken were unsafe for drinking. The third showed that the sample was good. The balance of probability is that in its present condition this well is unsafe.

It is stated to be located in the bottom of a ravine which is a natural water course and flooded in the spring. The protection of the mouth of this well might be a matter of some difficulty, but it is also stated that the water course can be tapped at a point above high water mark. Unless, as is not probable, the main source of supply which feeds the well is contaminated, I do not see any reason why it cannot be so protected from surface pollution as to make it safe. The fact that one sample was safe would seem to indicate that the main source is not contaminated.
I should think that a new well should be dug at a higher elevation and surrounded by a fence to enclose an area at least 100 feet square and that the new well should be capped and a pipe brought out of it so that the pumping station could be located outside the fence. It seems probable from the depth of the present well that this could be done so that a shallow well pump could be used. The engineer has examined this well and has sent in samples of water to bacteriologists who have never seen it. A bacteriological report can only refer to the sample which is received at the laboratory. It seems to me that a complete sanitary survey of the neighbourhood is required, particularly as there has been a great difference of opinion. The Provincial Government should have a man, or if not, I am very sure that there is a military sanitary officer at Winnipeg whose judgment on the matter would be reliable.

E.L. Stone, M.B.
Director of Medical Services
November 13, 1929.

Memorandum:

HONOURABLE CHARLES STEWART,

I am attaching hereto extracts from the file relating to the Emmington farm as a site for the proposed new Indian Residential School at Birtle. Several other properties have been examined, but none is suitable.

You will note that Mr. Commissioner Graham is really the only one to condemn the Emmington farm. Reverend Mr. Curry was principal of our school at Albert and is recognized as a good farmer and stock raiser. As he is strongly in favour of this property, I am inclined to give it consideration, particularly as it is the only one in the vicinity of Birtle that is at all suitable.

As far as the water supply is concerned, the quantity is ample and those best qualified to judge believe that a good quality can be secured and maintained. I should be glad to have your instructions.

Duncan C. Scott

[Handwritten note:]
I have an extra set of enclosures in my desk.
Mr. Edmunson has a section of land on the main Provincial Highway, Winnipeg to Edmonton. About half of the section is under cultivation, 87 acres summer fallowed last year. This is a good clean farm, well suited for mixed farming; has a fine stone house with bath; a small house for his farmer; a barn, fair condition. It will not meet our need but certainly has considerable value. There are about ten portable graineries. And this place has the four things I specially had in mind in looking for a good location; plenty of good land for agriculture; a good building site; good drainage; and last and most important an abundant supply of good water. This water supply cannot be valued for our purpose less than $5000. It is of choice quality. This farm is as close to Foxwarren as it is to Birtle. Here we are on the C. P. R. Winnipeg - Edmonton Br. and have two trains daily, each way. Mr. Edmunson is asking $25.00 an acre for this property. To my mind for our purpose this is a snap. This is a farm Mr. Edmunson has made ample to retire on. And would be a revenue producer from the very start. This property is slightly rolling and I have picked out a site that would be a commanding situation for the new school, slightly higher than the highway or any of the surrounding district, and would admirably lend itself to making the school on such a site an imposing structure. Something that would be a real attraction on this much travelled Provincial Highway.
I went to this place first and I consider it most unsuitable. The farm is badly broken up with coulees and stone ridges, and 50% of the land is covered with bluffs, and above all, the land is, to say the least, dirty. When Mr. Currie stated that this was a clean farm he did not state facts. I doubt very much whether Mr. Edmanson made sufficient on this land to retire on, which he states he did.

To put buildings costing $80,000.00 on this land is the last thing in the world I would recommend. I do not think you could get any expert to pass this farm as being suitable. It has a good well, it is true, but this is all it has to recommend it.
That evening we arranged with the owner of the land to secure an engine and the necessary equipment and on the following morning we tested the well for water supply. It would seem reasonable to expect a permanent supply of water. Regarding the quality, I may say that it has no unpleasant taste and I am by mail this morning forwarding you two one quart sealers. One of the containers was boiled before being used. This is marked on the sealer, in case you wish to have the bacteriological test made. The other was well washed and rinsed with the well water before being filled.

SURFACE: This is a well-drained piece of land with several shallow water courses. There are practically no indications of sloughs although poplar trees and some willow brush are dotted over the farm. The property presents a rather ragged appearance. There is no reason why once a large number of these bluffs are ploughed up that the farm would not have a good appearance. There are about seventy acres of land that is quite stony in places.

SOIL: There appeared to be about 12 inches of solid clay soil. In most places the solid clay soil appeared to be immediately below the black soil and other places we found a whitish gravelly clay between the black soil and the more solid clay below. It is my opinion that the soil would be easy to work and because of being well-drained could be cultivated early in the spring. Excepting on the stony part I believe the soil would be quite productive and would grow good crops of grain, grasses and leguminous crops.

WEEDS: Canada thistle is a predominating weed at the present time. The wild oats were also in evidence and one field appeared to have stink weed. We also found three patches of two or three acres each with couch grass and in one of the fields I noticed a number of patches of couch grass from six to ten feet long and three to four feet wide. There were a few plants of sow thistle. Given careful cultivation and proper crop rotation for a few years I believe that most of the weeds could be brought under control without too great an effort.

BUILDING SIZE: The main objections to my mind to this property are the stoney area in the centre and the fact that there is a road allowance between the two half sections.

REPORT OF DIRECTOR OF MEDICAL SERVICES, INDIAN AFFAIRS, FOLLOWING BACTERIOLOGICAL REPORT ON SAMPLES SUBMITTED BY MR. TINLIN.

The water submitted for examination from the Birtle School site was in two jars, one of which was stated to be sterilized and the other rinsed with the water itself. The sterilized jar shows contamination in a moderate degree and the unsterilized one in a marked degree. Neither of these samples of water would be suitable for drinking purposes without treatment.

A test of this sort is of very little value by itself. If the well is open it is subject to contamination which would not occur if it were closed and protected. If the surroundings were bad the water would be polluted, but might be rendered safe by cleaning up the ground near the well, removing possible manure piles, etc. There is no information on these points, and it is therefore impossible to say whether the well, as distinct from the samples, is a safe well or not.

The test for hardness indicates that the water is soft and should be suitable for boiler use as water goes in the west.
A rather deep coulee runs through the farm and along the bottom of this coulee I noticed two or three wells that were apparently abandoned and not in use. The well that is now the source of water supply for the farm is located in the bottom of the coulee and is in the path of a natural water course during the spring break-up. The well was found to be 6' diameter and 15' deep and contained 4 feet of water.

An examination of the well showed that about 10 feet of clay overlaid the gravel and the well penetrated the gravel only two feet. The gravel appeared to continue two feet below the bottom of the well. The gravel was very fine. This well has been in existence many years and has never shown any signs of failure.

The pumping test carried out on this well was a rather severe one, some 15,650 gallons being pumped in two days, or sufficient to supply for one week the anticipated requirements of the proposed Indian School. This well is a shallow surface one located in a coulee and contrary to expectations appears to be fed from an ample reservoir. The water is pleasant to the taste and is comparatively soft. From the results of the pumping test I am of the opinion that this well will provide ample water supply for the proposed Indian School. If utilised for this purpose, however, it will be necessary to tap the reservoir 25 to 30 feet away so as to get away from the bottom of the coulee.

A sample of the water was taken from this well at noon on October 3rd after some 11,000 gallons had been pumped out, special care being taken in the handling of the sample. Within twenty-four hours it was in the Bacteriological Laboratory of the Department of Health and Public Welfare of the Province of Manitoba for analysis. Their report shows that Colon Basilli was present; the bacterial plate count per c.c. being 356. They report that the water is unsafe for drinking and unfit without treatment for the requirements of the proposed Indian School.
This water is clear as water can be, good to taste, has no bad odor when taken from the well, nor when left standing several days - nor when boiled. For about 15 years the community have used it and with no ill effects.

Mr. Edmonson is not satisfied with Mr. Cow's report and he has sent other samples of water out of this well to two or more places for analysis.

This evening about 6 P.M. Mr. Edmonson called and gave me the attached report of a sample of water from his well. This sample was sent to the University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask.

The report speaks for itself. Mr. Edmonson has another report at home, that was secured from another reliable college, that he has promised to let me have. This report is also favorable as to the quality of this water.

If there was any doubt in my mind on this Edmonson site, I would never say a word. But it is such an ideal site "Building Site" "Drainage" "Water Location" and a very fair farm, with good soil. The two faults with the farm are in places there are some stones, and it has some ravines, not deep, but enough to make it "rolling". The ravines also serve good purposes and have advantages as well as disadvantages.

I will show you that it can be developed into a profitable beauty spot. The building site is outstanding and lends itself to making a school on such a site a prominent landmark on this much travelled Provincial Highway, and present indications are that the coming summer may see the Prov. Hydro pass this property. It is sure to come before long - if not next year.
November 6th, 1929.

Memorandum:

The present property of the Birtle Indian Residential School consists of 50 acres, on which the buildings are situated, and a quarter section farm, nearly 3 miles to the north east. The 50 acres itself is very hilly and stoney and is only partly suitable for garden purposes and pasture. The land to the east, south and west of the school property is all hilly and is cut up by the Birdtail creek. The town of Birtle is situated immediately to the south. To the north of the school, there is the C. P. R. Winnipeg-Edmonton line, and it may be possible to find suitable farm land nearer than the quarter section at present owned.

The nature of the water supply for the school has not been reported recently; but I understand that, for cooking and drinking, they secure water from a deep well, 800 yards from the school, on neighbouring property. This water is quite hard. They store rain water from the roof, in a large cement cistern and use this for the laundry. All water used for sewage disposal, fire protection, cleaning, etc., is secured from the C. P. R. pumping plant, at a pressure of 40 lbs.

Russell J. Carrier

Bupt. of Indian Education.
November 21/29

Mrs Jas Speer,
Birtle,
Manitoba.

Dear Madam,

A bacteriological examination of a sample of water received from you on Nov 19th shows no bacteriological contamination that would render it unfit for drinking purposes.

Yours truly,

Fred T. Cadham, M.D.

SIR:

Under date of January 30th, 1920 the Department of Indian Affairs, Ottawa, requested the Director of Water Power and Reclamation to instruct his District Chief Engineer at Winnipeg to make an examination of the present site of the Birtle School and submit a report "Advising if he considers a satisfactory water supply can be had at this point, also recommendations regarding the sewage system." On February 16th the writer made an examination of the present site of the Birtle School preparatory to preparing the report asked for.

Location of Birtle Indian School.

The present Indian School at Birtle is situated on the N.E.¼, Sec. 6, Tp. 17, Rge. 26, West of the Principal Meridian, and is located on the outskirts of the town of Birtle. The town of Birtle is situated in the Birdtail valley, which valley at this point is approximately 200 feet deep and one mile wide. The Canadian Pacific Railway does not pass through the town but crosses the Birdtail valley three miles west of Birtle, and Birtle Station is located on top of the plateau about 2,500 feet north of the centre of the town. The present school is located on the north slope of the valley, about 2,500 feet from the centre of the town and about midway between the Creek and Birtle Station.

J. T. Johnston, Esq.,
Director, Dominion Water Power & Reclamation Service,
Department of the Interior,
Ottawa, Ontario.
Water Supply for Present School.

The Indian School at Birdle obtains its water supply from the Canadian Pacific Railway. The railway has a water tank adjacent to their station for supplying their engines, and obtain their water supply from Birdtail Creek. Their pumping plant is located on the creek bank almost directly south of the station and about 3,000 feet distant. The pumping plant consists of a Triplex pump, manufactured by Goulds, with 7 inch plunger and 8 inch stroke and belt connected to a 25 h.p. Semi-Diesel oil engine. The intake consists of a reservoir 8' x 8' x 12', located just above high water mark, but directly connected to the river by a ten-inch pipe line. The water is pumped to the water tank through a six-inch cast iron pipe line. The normal daily requirements of the railway vary from 20,000 to 100,000 gallons, depending upon traffic conditions.

This pipe line passes within 300 feet of the school and is tapped at this point by a pipe line leading to a tank in the upper story of the building. The school has always had an ample supply of water. The water is not filtered or treated in any way.

Very low run-off conditions prevailed during the summer and autumn of 1929 throughout the area drained by Birdtail Creek and similar conditions have prevailed during the present winter, resulting in very little flow in the creek. However, the creek is fed by numerous small springs along the valley and has never been known to go completely dry. To date there has always been ample water to supply the demand.

Water Supply for New School.

The only source of water supply for a new school located on the old site is from Birdtail Creek, or from springs in the valley adjacent to the stream. Whether springs can be located to supply sufficient water for the new school can only be ascertained by borings, not feasible at the present time.

Two schemes for obtaining water supply to the new school are open for consideration:

(1) The Department can construct their own intake, install their own pumping equipment, and lay a pipe line direct to an elevated water tank in the vicinity of the school.

(2) The Department can make arrangements with the Canadian Pacific Railway Company to derive their water supply from the Company's pipe line as is now being done. This involves laying a new pipe line from the point where the C. P. R. water line would be tapped to an elevated water tank near the school.
With either scheme it will probably be advisable to erect a 10,000 gallon wood stave tank with tower and employ a gravity system through the school and other buildings. This tank will necessarily have to contain a filter bed and a chlorinating plant will be necessary for the school water supply system. In this report I will not attempt to give any detailed or accurate estimate of the cost of water supply to the school, such not being possible until the actual location is chosen. However, a very rough estimate has been made of the necessary outlay for each scheme in order to make comparisons.

**Scheme No. 1.**

| Item                                      | Cost     |
|-------------------------------------------|----------|
| Construction of Intake                    | $300.00  |
| Pump house, building, drains, etc.        | $1,200.00|
| Pumping Equipment, oil engine, etc.       | $1,800.00|
| Pipe Line - Pipe - Excaviation, laying and backfilling | $3,000.00|
| Tank - Tower, all enclosed & Filter bed   | $6,000.00|
| Chlorinating Plant                        | $1,800.00|
| **Total**                                 | **$14,100.00** |

**Scheme No. 2.**

| Item                                      | Cost     |
|-------------------------------------------|----------|
| Pipe Line - C.P.R. Line to School         | $625.00  |
| Tank - Tower, all enclosed & Filter bed   | $6,000.00|
| Chlorinating Plant                        | $1,800.00|
| **Total**                                 | **$8,425.00** |

It will be seen that Scheme No. 2 permits a saving of approximately $6,000.00 in capital outlay. Furthermore the writer is of the opinion that favorable arrangements can be made with the Canadian Pacific Railway Company whereby their annual charge for supplying an ample supply of water for the school would be less than the annual cost of operating a separate pumping station as outlined in Scheme No. 1.

**Sewage System.**

At the present school the sewage passes into a septic tank and the outflow is allowed to spread over the slope below. The present site and the site in the vicinity of the present one affords splendid drainage facilities and a satisfactory sewerage disposal system can be secured. The soil is a hard clay overlying a scapstone formation. It will be advisable to pass the outflow from the septic tank through a disposal bed, otherwise contamination of the water supply might result.
Conclusions.

For a new school erected on or in the vicinity of the site of the old school, the natural source of water supply is Birdtail Creek. This stream will doubtless always provide an ample water supply. However, I would like to point out that Birdtail Creek is ordinarily a small stream flowing in a deep wide valley at this point and subject to wide variation in flow, but usually high water only prevails at the time of the spring freshets. The valley is extensively utilized for grazing purposes and during heavy rains drainage into the stream from the slopes of the valley is rapid. Under such conditions the water is unfit and unsafe for domestic use and cannot of course be made fit and safe by filtration and chlorination. The degree of chlorination necessary to ensure a safe water supply may be such as to result in an unsatisfactory supply for domestic purposes.

Assistant District Chief Engineer.

Sir,

Confirming my telegram of this afternoon, I beg to advise you that in compliance with instructions contained in your letter No; 106-1-9 dated 2nd May, with which you enclosed a copy of your letter to Mr Currie, the Principal of the Birtle Residential School, Mr Currie and I met the Birtle Town Council on two occasions, to discuss the proposed purchase of Blocks 211, 212, 213, and 214, and the N.W.¼ of Sec; 5, Twp;17 R: 26 W.P.M. all being the property of the Town of Birtle, for the new residential school purposes.

There was no difficulty in securing an option on the four blocks, but the Council was not at first disposed to sell that portion of the N.W.¼ of Sec; 5 lying south of the Bird Tail River, on account of the fact that they may require it some time, for the purpose of creating a lake by damming the river, and making a summer resort. They have plans, blue prints, and estimates for this purpose, but these were drawn up 25 years ago, and have never been utilized.

Without this portion of the quarter, however, Mr Currie did not want any of it at all, as there would be nothing of any use on the portion north of the river, the best pasture being on the south, which also has on it about 300 cords of good poplar wood.

The Council then suggested selling the north portion -

portion at a price of $800.00, and leasing the south portion to the Department for a ten year period, at $25.00 per year. This, I did not approve of, deeming it best that the Department should own the property outright, by purchase.

Deputy Minister of Justice,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:-

RE INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL,
BIRTLE, AND S.W. 16-17-26 W.

In this matter I wish to report that search has been made of all properties which the writer understands are used for school purposes at Birtle. The school itself is located within the limits of the Town of Birtle and there is also a quarter section of land located in the Rural Municipality of Birtle, used for farm purposes.

The letter of instructions was not quite clear as to whether or not all the properties should be transferred to His Majesty the King in the right of the Dominion of Canada. For your information we are reporting in separate letters on the respective properties and in this letter will deal particularly with the south west quarter of section 16 in township 17 and range 26.

This quarter section, located in the Rural Municipality of Birtle, stands in the name of the Board of Trustees of the Presbyterian Church in Canada. The title is under the Torrens System and is clear of encumbrances, and there are no taxes outstanding against the land. We are sending you in this matter the original certificate of search which we have obtained from the Land Titles Office, also Tax Certificate showing the property clear of taxes to the end of 1929. The title is perfectly satisfactory, in fact it is the best obtainable, and a transfer from the Board of Trustees of the Presbyterian Church in Canada to His Majesty the King in the right of the Dominion of Canada would give a perfectly satisfactory title. I shall be glad to be instructed whether this particular parcel is to be transferred.

I am writing you a separate letter regarding the properties within the limits of the Town of Birtle which will be forwarded by early mail.

Yours faithfully,

(sgd) John W. Pratt.
Sir:-

I would be obliged to have your instructions in this matter.

Sir:

I have your B-5737 of the 26th instant, with reference to the purchase of the Indian Residential School property at Birtle from the Presbyterian Church. The Department does not intend to acquire the S. W. ¼ of Sec. 16, T. 17, R. 26, reference to which is made in the enclosed copy of a letter from your Agent of the 17th instant. The parcel to be acquired is approximately 25 acres and is situate in the N. E. ¼ of Sec. 6 - within the limits of the town of Birtle. I note that your Agent will report in connection with this parcel in the near future.

I now write to state that the Department wishes to acquire several other parcels for the use of the Birtle Indian Residential School. Options have been taken on these, and I should be grateful if you would have your agent search title and, if found satisfactory, prepare conveyances. The parcels in question are:-

1. Fractional S. E. ¼ of Sec. 7, T. 17, R. 26, W. P., approximately 125 acres, owned by Mrs. W. Patterson - the consideration being $800.

2. W. ½ of Sec. 8, T. 17, R. 26, W. P., 320 acres, owned by Mrs. J. Patterson - the consideration being $6,000.

3. N. W. ¼ of Sec. 5, T. 17, R. 26, W. P., 160 acres; and Blocks 211, 212, 213 and 214, situate within the limits of the town of Birtle, in the N. E. ¼ of Sec. 6, T. 17, R. 26, W. P., all owned by the town of Birtle - the consideration being $1,500.

In the instrument of conveyance in connection with the property which is owned by the town of Birtle, there should be inserted a clause, giving the vendors the right to purchase, at any time, for the sum of $500, that portion of the N. W. ¼ of Sec. 5, T. 17, R. 26, W. P., which is south of the creek.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy Secretary.

Dear Mrs. McKerrell:

With reference to earlier correspondence concerning land for the proposed new Birtle Indian Residential School, I have now to inform you that the Department is arranging to purchase the undermentioned parcels in addition to the present school site. The properties are now being appraised and title is being searched:

1. Blocks 211, 212, 213 and 214, north of the present school site, within the limits of the town of Birtle, in the N.E. ¼ of Sec. 6, approximately 20 acres, owned by the town of Birtle - the consideration being $500.

2. N.W. ¼ of Sec. 5, which is to the east of the present school site, 160 acres, owned by the town of Birtle - the consideration being $1,000. (The vendors have insisted that a clause be inserted in the instrument of conveyance in this connection, giving them the right to purchase that portion of the quarter section which is south of the creek, in the event that it is needed for municipal purposes, such as a park, etc. Mr. Indian Agent Lazenby reports that he believes the town of Birtle will likely never exercise this right.)

Dear Sir;

Re: Birtle Indian Residential School.

Acting on the instructions contained in yours of the 8th inst., I immediately got in touch with Claydon Ltd., and Mr. Gow by wire and succeeded in having Mr. Mitchell of Claydon Ltd., and Mr. Gow meet me at Birtle yesterday.

We thoroughly examined the property owned by the Dept. of Indian Affairs and selected a site for the new school considerably north of the present school, and at a much higher level; in fact the site is on almost the highest portion of the property. It is the only one that would in any way allow of adequate playground facilities. The whole property is really the side of a hill sloping from north at the C.P.R. right-of-way, to Birtle Creek at the south.

Mr. Gow had in mind a site on a lower level, about halfway between the selected site and the old school, with a view to obtaining the water supply by gravity from the C.P.R. tank; but upon investigation we found this far too crowded to allow of playgrounds around the school. I believe it is now Mr. Gow's intention to pipe, by gravity, from the C.P.R. tank to the school into a filter tank and then use the usual pressure tanks to distribute to the fixtures.

The selected site is dependent upon the closing of two or three unused streets; but this matter was thoroughly gone into with Mr. Lazenby, the Agent, and the town solicitor, who assured us that this was only a matter of form in the final passing of the necessary bye-law as it had already been passed by the town council.

The school will now face South and the barns and stables will all be to the East so that it becomes necessary to throw the plan completely over. I have instructed the Contractors to do this, and stated that I would ask you

1.
ask you for two sets of the plans printed from the reverse side of the tracings, as this will help quite a little even though the lettering will be reading backwards. Could you forward these to them at an early date?

The matter of the septic tank was gone into and this will be located to the south east of the building. Mr. Gow will of course be going into details of both this and the water supply at greater length.

I have arranged with Mr. Mitchell the foreman to let me know as soon as he has the excavation cut when I will run down for another inspection, and so on about once a week until I receive further instructions from you.

The site to be excavated is covered with a thick growth of small poplar trees, and in view of the fact that the contractor had his men and equipment there ready to start I instructed him to clear this; and as the specifications state that the site will be cleared by the Dept., there will be a small extra on this.

Your obedient servant,

Sir:

As requested in your letter of July 8th, I met Mr. Swan at Birtle on the 16th, and a site for the new Indian School was chosen. Mr. Swan said he would be writing you fully with respect to the selection of the site and some matters pertaining to the closing of streets and opening up a new road by arrangement with the Town of Birtle.

As you will have noticed from the contoured plan forwarded you some time ago, the area in which the new school was to be located is very broken with a steep descent to the creek. The only level areas sufficiently spacious for a school site appear to be the present school site or on the level plateau within about 500 feet of the Canadian Pacific Railway Right-of-Way. The latter area was selected as the most advantageous site for the school.

However, the selection of this particular site will add somewhat to the cost of the water installation and will also increase the operating costs after the system is put into use. The selection of the site on the plateau near the top of the valley renders it undesirable to depend upon a gravity system entirely, as the storage tank would have to be erected too high. It is now recommended that an elevated tank be constructed about 20 to 25 feet above the ground elevation, so that water service in the basement of the building be supplied by gravity. A pressure tank system will be installed in the building to supply the three upper floors. This system will be operated practically the same as the new Indian School at Brandon. It is also suggested that arrangements be made for the Canadian Pacific Railway to do the pumping to the tank.

The site selected offers no difficulty in the matter of drainage or sewerage disposal. I am arranging to have plans and drawings prepared for water supply and sewerage disposal systems, together with estimates of costs. This will involve seeing what arrangements can be made with Canadian Pacific Railway officials in Winnipeg, re the cost of pumping of water.

If it is your wish that this office proceed with the preparation of drawings, and of the proposed layouts and estimates, I will be pleased to submit the same at an early date. I would, in any case,
strongly recommend that the water supply system and sewage disposal systems be proceeded with at any early date as possible, as being mostly outside work it can be most economically performed during the summer.

Your obedient servant,

Memorandum:

HONOURABLE THOMAS G. MURPHY,

With reference to the selection of a site for the Birtle Indian Residential School, I may say that, at first, the Department was considering the Provincial Demonstration Farm, 2 miles south of the town. In March of last year, the Manitoba Government withdrew their offer to sell the property, as strong opposition to the proposal had been expressed by the people of the district. I then considered the advisability of locating the new school building on the Waywayseecappo Indian reserve, which is 20 miles north of Birtle, not far from Rossburn. It was pointed out, however, that there were many advantages if the school could be kept nearer the town of Birtle.

Properties in the vicinity of Birtle were then considered. The Edmonton farm, 4 miles north of Birtle, and the Brayshaw property, 12 miles east, were examined and were both found unsatisfactory. Mr. Commissioner Graham, of Regina, could not agree with Principal Currie that the Edmonton property was suitable. The Brayshaw farm had many disadvantages and the Honourable Mr. Stewart directed that a site near Birtle be secured.

In July of last year, Mr. Graham was instructed to immediately secure options on suitable farms near Birtle and to test for domestic water supply at the Department's expense. The Edmonton farm and the Scantlebury Brothers property, both 2 miles south of Birtle, were considered. In the meantime, there were still representations from the people of Birtle that the Edmonton property, north of the town, should be given further consideration. The Dominion Water Powers of the Department of the Interior were asked to report in connection with the water supply. They reported against the reliability of the supply on the Edmonton and Scantlebury properties. I had the Edmonton property examined by the Superintendent of the Dominion Demonstration Farm at Brandon, who confirmed Principal Currie's statement that it would be fairly suitable for school purposes. Mr. Graham's objection was that the land was stony and cut up. The Dominion Water
Power Branch were asked to report on the water supply there. This was found to be fairly ample, but unsatisfactory for domestic purposes without treatment. The well did not appear to be fed by a flowing spring and it would be extremely difficult to ascertain where the contamination took place.

No decision could be reached last year because of the failure to locate a farm on which there was good arable land and a suitable water supply. During the winter, it was decided to favourably consider the present site and to examine farm land near the school. Principal Currie was satisfied that the school could be successfully conducted on the old location. The school would be near the town of Birtle and old associations could be continued. One very important consideration - that of electric power - was settled. A good building site with suitable drainage was present. Playgrounds and gardens could be prepared at no great cost. There is a good train service to Birtle and the site is close to the station.

The Town Council of Birtle urged that the old location be considered and they offered to sell at a fair price the actual building site and suitable pasture. The only disadvantage was the nature of the land in the vicinity and the Principal and others were satisfied to make the best of it.

In January, last, the Dominion Water Power Branch were asked to report on the water supply and sewage disposal possibilities. It was found that an ample supply could be secured from the C.P.R., and, after chlorination, it would be entirely suitable. In March, it was decided to use the old location and to purchase enough land in the vicinity so that farming could be conducted.

I may add that the Ebwank farm, on the south side of the valley at Birtle, was mentioned at this time, but, as it was much less convenient to the railway and as the people at Birtle were in favour of the old location, the proposal was not seriously considered.

The following properties, as shown on the next page, have been acquired. These parcels comprise a total of 655 acres, which is not too much, considering the nature of the land. The total price is $8,301, or an average of $12.67 per acre. The land has been valued by an independent appraiser at $8,446, which figure does not include a price on the 50 acres which we are securing from the church. This is worth at least another $500, so that the independent appraisal for the total is approximately $9,000.

The undersigned has the honour to report that the Department of Indian Affairs has negotiated for the purchase of land required for the new Birtle Indian Residential School, in the Province of Manitoba. The lands in question may be described as follows:-

The Committee of the Privy Council have had before them a Report, dated 11th September, 1930, from the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs, submitting that the Department of Indian Affairs has negotiated for the purchase of lands required for the new Birtle Indian Residential School, in the Province of Manitoba. The lands in question may be described as follows:-

(All being in T. 17, R. 26, W.P.)

A. Fractional N.E.¼ Sec. 6, approximately 30 acres, to be purchased from Presbyterian Church Missionary Society, at a consideration of $1,000, to be used for playgrounds, garden and pasture.

B. Blocks 211, 212, 213 and 214, Plan No. in N.W.¼ Sec. 6, approximately 30 acres, to be purchased from the town of Birtle, at a consideration of $500.00. This is the actual building site.

C. N.W.¼ Sec. 6, 150 acres, to be purchased from the town of Birtle, for a consideration of $1,000.00. This quarter is required for pasture and to gain access to the creek. There is some wood (approximately 300 cords) on it.

D. W.E.¼ Sec. 6, 320 acres, to be purchased from Mrs. J. Patterson, for a consideration of $6,000.00. This is the only farm land within easy reach of the school site. All recognize that it is not good farm land, but Principal Currie states that it can be made to meet the need.

E. Fractional S.E.¼ Sec. 7, approximately 125 acres, to be purchased from Mrs. W. Patterson, for a consideration of $500.00. The part of this parcel south of the creek is required to round out the property. The northern part of the parcel is good pasture. There is a good well on this property and some wood.

These parcels comprise a total of 685 acres. The total price is $8,301 or an average of $12.37 per acre. The land has been valued by an independent appraiser at $6,445, exclusive of Parcel A, which is considered by the department to be worth not less than $500.00, making a total value of the properties of approximately $9,000.00.

The Honourable
the Superintendent General
of Indian Affairs.
The title to these properties is being searched by an agent of the Department of Justice.

The Minister recommends that authority be granted for the purchase by the Department of Indian Affairs of the aforesaid lands for the purpose hereinabove mentioned, at the said price of $5,301. Funds for this purpose are available from Parliamentary Appropriation.

The Committee concur in the foregoing recommendation and submit the same for approval.

Dear Sirs:

And our W.M.S. must obtain its title from the trustees for the continuing Presbyterian Church. Thomson, who is acting in the matter of conveyancing for the continuing Presbyterian Church but he is unable to give me any information as to how things are getting on. Dear Sirs; Re Indian School Lands, Birtle, Man.

After the completion of the new Indian School buildings at Birtle, Man. the Town Council of that town passed a by-law closing the road allowance north of sections 5 and 6, Township 17, Range 26 W., which passed through the grounds of the new school.

I am the owner of the east half of section 8, and section 9, lying to the east of the land which has recently been purchased by you i.e. the west half of section 8.

Due to the location of these lands with respect to the Canadian Pacific Railway right of way, and also to the Birdtail River the most direct means of access to my property lay across the west half of section 8. This route was used for some thirty years by consent of the former owner of the west half of section 8.

However, anticipating that this land might be sold, I applied to the Canadian Pacific Railway some years ago for a crossing at the south west corner of my property to allow use of the road allowance north of section 5, and 6. Now, however, due to the location of the new school buildings, the town has passed a by-law closing this road allowance.

On hearing of this I placed a protest with the Provincial Government, who then refused to ratify the by-law until such time as the matter was settled to the satisfaction of all parties.

I would like to have if possible some legal arrangement granting right of access to my property across the west half of section 8-17, 26 W. I would be glad to have your views on this matter.

Yours very truly,

(Mrs.) Katherine Patterson.

Memorandum

The Minister,

The attached correspondence from Mr. Frank Mansaring to Col. H.A. Mullins, M.P., refers to a complication which has arisen as a result of a sale by the Town of Birtle to this Department of the N.W.¼ Sec. 5, Tp. 17, R. 26, which were purchased for the purpose of the Birtle Indian residential school. One of the terms in connection with this sale was that the Town agreed to close all roads adjacent to the property purchased and to take in exchange the road across the S.E.¼ Sec. 7, Tp. 17, R. 26. This involved the official closing of the regulation road allowance between Secs. 5 and 8, but the road along this allowance had never been constructed and on account of the nature of the ground on which it is located could not have been opened except by an expenditure of several thousands of dollars, on account of the fact that it is very rocky and along the edge of a deep gully, as you will note from the topography shown on the attached plan.

Mr. Johnson, whose house and farm buildings are located on the N.W.¼ Sec. 9 in the position indicated on the plan, leases the E.½ Sec. 8 from Mrs. Katherine Paterson, Winnipeg. (This property is shown in yellow on the plan and adjoins the school property which is shown in blue on the plan.) It appears that prior to the acquisition of the W.½ Sec. 8 for the school that the former owner of the W.½, who was the brother of the owner of the E.½, consented to the use by the owner of the E.½ of the trails indicated in red on the plan.
The Principal of the school reports that Mr. Johnson has been a source of considerable trouble for sometime and that he has continued to cross the school farm, cutting and tearing down fences belonging to the school, smashing locks off gates and making for himself a trail through the school crops of barley and potatoes. The road along the North and West of Sec.8 is a good gravelled road to which Mr. Johnson has access over his own trail in N.W.¼ Sec.9 as indicated on the plan. The road allowance between Secs.8 and 9 has not been opened and Mr. Johnson has this road allowance under cultivation.

It appears to the Department that if Mr. Johnson is to be provided with any other outlet than that now available over the road allowance to the North of Sec.9 that the responsibility of providing such access rests with the Town of Birtle and not with this Department.

The Principal of the school has strongly objected to Mr. Johnson having a trail across the school property and it is considered that, if the Town finds it necessary to provide Mr. Johnson with access across Sec.8 by expropriating a portion of the school land, the proper place to establish such a road would be straight across Sec.8 between the N. and S. ¼ sections. This was intimated to the Town by the Principal of the school who also suggested that in that event the school would construct a fence on one side of this road through the school property, if the Town would provide a fence on the other side. Mr. Johnson made objections to this by insisting that such a road should be a public road through the W.½ Sec.8 but that it must cease to be a public road upon entering the E.½ of the Section and that he would install a gate at that point to prevent anyone continuing along the road into his farm. The Town Council then took the attitude that they would not open a road leading to a blind end as it was considered necessary that a road of this nature should continue to the road allowance between Secs.8 and 9 and as the Municipality had offered to open a road allowance between the N.½ Secs.8 and 9, it would supply a continuous route from the roads now in
existence along the North boundaries of Secs.8 and 9. This, of course, was not acceptable to Mr. Johnson as he has this portion of the road allowance under cultivation.

In view of the circumstances, I do not consider it to be either necessary or desirable for the Department to permit Mr. Johnson to cross the school property over an unauthorized trail, as it seems to me to be a question which should be dealt with by the Town of Birtle.

Deputy Superintendent General.

Owing to the fact that the Town of Birtle is at present not in a position financially, to erect the fences to enclose the roadway proposed, it will be necessary to have a gate set at each end of the roadway, which will have to be opened and closed every time anyone uses the road, and Mr Johnson undertakes to keep these gates closed and to instruct his men also to keep them closed.

Re; Clause 3. Though Mr Johnson is the "Purchaser" of the farm he now occupies, (Mrs Katherine Paterson being the vendor), there appears a strong probability that, owing to his not being able to live up to his obligations, the vendor may re-possess the farm, and this clause was put in at my suggestion so that if Mr Johnson at any time leaves his farm, the right to use the proposed 30 foot roadway across the school farm, automatically expires. This would avoid the possibility of the roadway becoming established as a public road by usage and custom.

Clause 4, is self explanatory.

Before the Mayor of Birtle can sign the above agreement, it will of course be necessary that the Council pass a resolution authorizing him to do so; as his signature would bind the Town to erect the two fences as soon as they became in a position financially to do so. Then there is the possibility that Mrs Katherine Paterson would not care to sign the agreement on account of Clause No; 3.

The present proposal is to have the agreement drafted and submitted to those concerned for signature, and if all these are procured, to then submit it to the Department for approval or otherwise.

I may say that Principal Currie of the Birtle Indian Residential School approved of the terms of the agreement.

A further report will be forwarded to the Department in due course.

Schools Branch,

Arrangements have at last been completed to obtain title from the Town of Birtle for those portions of the road allowance between Secs.5,6,7 and 8 shown indicated in green on the attached blueprint. The Municipal Commissioner would not approve of the Town By Laws Nos.282 and 288, closing these roads, until Mr. Johnson's objection was removed. This was accomplished by transferring to the Province for a right of way 30 feet in width along the North of the S.W.-¼ Sec.8 to provide access to the occupant of the E.½ Sec.8. This has been completed and the Town is issuing title to the portions which were acquired.

It is necessary that these be filed under the Torrens system. The Registrar's fee for this is $52.00. This fee varies according to the valuation of the property, including the buildings thereon, which has been filled out by the Agent of the Department of Justice at $10,000.00. I presume this amount has been arrived at by interviewing the Agent and the Principal of the school. In this regard I would say that the Department made arrangements with the Canadian Pacific Railway Company for water supply for this school from the Company's pipe-line - the school authorities paying an annual charge for this service. Sir:

I wish to refer to a letter forwarded under date of June 15th last relating to a proposed dam across Birdtail Creek at Birtle, Manitoba. In that letter I stated that in my opinion the dam was not a necessity nor an advantage insofar as the Indian School at Birtle was concerned.

Birdtail Creek is one of the streams upon which we carried out hydrometric studies over a period of years. It is fed by springs and insofar as we are aware, it has never ceased to have some flow. However, during the past summer and this autumn there has been very little rainfall in the watershed and the flow in the stream is now very low. It is possible the springs may fail this winter as a result of the continued sub-normal rainfall conditions. Such failure would have serious consequences for the Indian School which is dependent upon the river for its water supply.

I understand that all efforts to have the dam constructed during the present summer under provisions of the Prairie Farm Rehabilitation Act, have failed since Birtle is not considered to be within the drought area. There is a strong local demand for the construction of the dam and while it does not exist in existence for two years or more will neither a necessity nor an advantage to the Indian School, yet it is now quite possible that the water supply might fail because of the extension of the dry area to the Birdtail Watershed. The construction of a dam now might avert a serious condition of water shortage this winter and I believe the Department of Indian Affairs would be justified in assisting in the construction of the dam.

Should such assistance be granted, it should be stipulated that the Municipality be required to operate the dam during the summer months in accordance with the directions of officials of the Department of Indian Affairs. This provision is necessary so that the pond could be emptied occasionally during the summer of low water to prevent repetition of the trouble experienced with algae growth during the summer of 1934. During that summer the flow in the river was quite low and the water in the pond became quite stagnant, permitting algae growth which when taken into the filter, chlorinator and water softener at the Indian School, caused a great deal of inconvenience at the school and was the cause of serious complaints from the Principal.

Your obedient servant,

D. B. Gow,
Acting District Chief Engineer.

REPORT ON DAM AT BIRTLE, MANITOBA

Early in June of the present year the Town of Birtle and the Rural Municipality of Birtle made representations to the Governments both of Manitoba and the Dominion, requesting that financial aid be granted to repair the dam on the Birdtail river just west of the town. They stated that the main part of the dam had been carried away by the high water of this spring, and pointed out that this had resulted in a serious water-shortage for many interests that had depended on the pond created by the dam for their supply for domestic and other uses.

The matter was referred to the Water Development Committee for attention, and on Monday, July 11th, an inspection of the dam was made by Messrs. Vallance, Russell and Attwood, the Dominion and Manitoba representatives on the Committee for Manitoba.

Following this inspection, the writer was instructed to proceed to Birtle, together with Mr. L. H. Carter, agricultural representative, and Mr. F. A. Dagk, office engineer, for the purpose of making a survey of the dam and securing definite information as to its value in providing a supply of water, particularly to the farming population of the district.

The party travelled by car to Birtle on July 16th, completed the field inspections on July 18th, and on the latter date returned to Winnipeg. The data secured are contained in this report and that of Mr. Carter, supplemented by the plans attached hereto.

HISTORICAL

This dam was built about the year 1886 to provide power for operating a small grist-mill and about 1894 was taken over by J. D. McArthur, who installed a saw-mill in place of the grist-mill. Subsequently the spillway portion of the dam was washed out, and it remained in this damaged condition until the year 1931.

In the latter year the Town of Birtle took over the dam and repaired it, in order to provide a permanent supply of water for the adjacent residents, whose wells and other sources of water were beginning to dry up as a result of deficient precipitation. This work was completed as a relief project at a cost of approximately $2500.00, of which the Dominion contributed $750.00, the Province, $450.00, and the Town, the remainder.

The dam operated satisfactorily until the spring break-up of this year, when a large mass of ice, borne by the swift current of the flooded stream, was forced against the spillway portion of the dam and carried part of it away. The gap so made was enlarged by the flowing water, and finally included the greater portion of the spillway. As a result of this damage, the river has now dropped to a low level, and the dam has entirely lost its effectiveness in providing a permanent pond as a source of water-supply.

DESCRIPTION OF DAM

The site of the dam is at the head of a former small rapid, one-half mile west of the town of Birtle. At this point the left bank of the river is high and rises steeply from the water's edge, whereas the right...
bank rises only two or three feet to a broad flat that extends for about three hundred feet northerly before commencing to rise gradually toward the main steep bank of the valley.

The dam is 410 feet long and extends from the south bank across the stream at the head of the rapid and then along the upstream edge of the flat on the northerly side. As reconstructed in 1931, the southerly end for about 100 feet consisted mainly of a low crib seven feet wide, filled with clay gravel and boulders and sheeted on the upstream and downstream sides. This crib was faced on the upstream side with a sloping fill of clay, heavily riprapped, and was backed on the downstream side with a fill of boulders.

The spillway occupied a length of about sixty feet of the crib work portion of the dam, and its crest was about three feet lower than the top of the upstream sheeting on the non-overflow section. Near the south end of the spillway was a fish-ladder, the upper end of which was 0.85 feet below the spillway level.

North of the spillway the dam consists of a clay fill about three hundred feet long extending along the flat to the main north bank. This fill has a top width of from twelve to eighteen feet, side slopes of about two horizontal to one vertical, and a maximum height of seven feet above natural ground-level. In 1931 the Town built a concrete coping-wall into the upstream edge of the top of the fill, and also placed riprap along the upper part of the upstream slope.

Near the north end of this embankment is a timber and concrete sluiceway, which formed the intake for the mills that formerly existed at the site. This sluiceway is controlled by a gate at the upper end and has been used from time to time to empty the reservoir. Below the lower end there is a small channel that leads to a bend of the main river downstream.

The damage done this year was confined to the cribwork portion of the dam, and was so extensive that the only way in which the dam could again be made operative is to replace this section entirely. No damage was done to the clay embankment, but this section had to be protected by sand-bags to prevent over-topping during the flood period, and should be raised about two feet to avoid the possibility of future damage.

The extent of the pond created by the dam, when operating, was not fully determined, but the water was said to be maintained at a uniform level for a distance of three miles upstream. Between the dam and the westerly border of the town the main body of the pond was one-half mile long, and averaged about four hundred and fifty feet wide. In this section the flats that are now exposed were formerly covered by from four to five feet of water.

The attached general plan (Plate No. 1), supplemented by the attached photographs, shows details of the dam in its present condition.

INTERESTS DEPENDENT ON DAM

The attached report by Mr. L. H. Carter, Agricultural Supervisor, sets forth the difficulties that have been experienced by the local farming population in securing a supply of water during the recent dry years, and shows that many of them have been dependent on the pond created by the dam, from which they have hauled...
water for domestic use and for their livestock. From the agricultural standpoint, therefore, it is very important that the dam be repaired and a dependable supply of water again made available.

The situation of the town of Birtle with respect to a water-supply is not so acute as that of the surrounding agricultural area, as the town lies in the lower part of the main river-valley and the wells have not gone dry. The maintenance of the pond above the dam has, however, distinct advantages for the people of the town by providing water for uses other than domestic, including its availability in case of fire.

A minor interest from the economic standpoint, but important in the view of all the local residents, is the value of the pond created by the dam as a recreational asset. The Town, since taking over the dam in 1971, has developed a small park and tourist camp just below the dam, and the pond above has been much used for boating and bathing.

RECOMMENDATION

In view of the fact that the local agricultural community depends so largely on the Birdtail river as a source of water-supply, and that such a supply can only be made definitely available, particularly during the winter months, by means of ponding the water at such depth that it will not freeze to the bottom, it is recommended that full financial assistance be granted to the Town of Birtle for the repair of the dam.

PROPOSED RECONSTRUCTION

In order to put the dam in shape to maintain the pond at its former level, the following operations are involved:

1. The site will have to be cleared of the remaining cribwork portion of the existing dam, and a new spillway section constructed as shown in location on Plate No. 1 and in detail on Plate No. 2 attached hereto.

2. The embankment portion of the dam should be raised about two feet (to elevation 101.0, local datum), in order to prevent overtopping during floods.

3. Stop-logs should be provided to secure an added depth of one-foot above the proposed spillway level.

4. A new fish-ladder should be constructed (not shown on plan), at the south end of the spillway.

In order to carry out this work, the site may be unwatered by placing material removed from the existing damaged structure along the upper edge of the gap through which the water now flows, and excavating a small ditch from the site to the foot of the rapid below. During construction, the flow of the stream can be carried through the existing sluice at the north end of the dam.

Sir:

I have for attention your letter of the 20th instant with reference to the proposed dam project on Birdtail river at Birtle. It is noted that considerable additional information is necessary before any action can be taken at Ottawa.

We are enclosing copy of a report by Mr. B. Hogarth, dated August 4th last, together with blue prints that supplies much of the information requested. The writer also discussed with Mr. J. C. Holden, Divisional Engineer of the Canadian Pacific Railway, the interests of the Railway Company with respect to the project. The project was also discussed with Mr. A. MacNamara, Deputy Minister, Department of Public Works of the Province of Manitoba, regarding the attitude of the Province. The interests of the Town of Birtle had previously been discussed with the Mayor and one of the aldermen on the occasion of their recent visit to Winnipeg.

Mr. Holden stated that the Railway is very anxious that there be an assured water supply at Birtle for their trains, that the Company is now replacing its water tank at that point, that it has contributed towards the maintenance of a dam in the past and is prepared to assist in the carrying out of this project. However, the Company is not prepared to make arrangements with the town itself as regards the reconstruction of the dam, but would prefer to act independently or in co-operation with the Dominion and Provincial Governments.

Mr. MacNamara stated that the Province was interested in the project inasmuch as it affects a municipality that is receiving relief assistance and that it had been represented that the reservoir would provide a water supply for many of the farmers in the vicinity who find their wells going dry and are in difficulty as regards water for their stock. However, it did not appear to come within the category of relief projects. He intimated, however, that the Province might contribute 10% of the cost in lieu of the relief that is being granted the Municipality, that the Dominion government might contribute 25% and the Municipality the balance, through assistance from the Canadian Pacific Railway and local interests.

The Town of Birtle would appear to the greatest beneficiary from the project as proposed. The people of Birtle do not use the river as a source of drinking water but claim that the reservoir does maintain the water level in the wells upon which they depend for their water supply. Undoubtedly the pond created is of major importance in the view of the townspeople because of the recreational features it provides and its attraction for tourists. The Municipality claims it is unable to provide the necessary money to reconstruct the dam without assistance.

The Department of Indian Affairs built the Birtle Indian Residential School in 1930, replacing the school that had been

J. T. Johnston, Esq.,
Director,
Dominion Water Power and Hydrometric Bureau, OTTAWA.
in existence there for many years. The school obtains its water supply from the Canadian Pacific Railway and is accordingly dependent upon Birdtail river as its source of supply. The Railway Company is under no obligation to provide a continuous water supply even though the school is charged for the water provided. The water consumption at the school is approximately 6,000 gallons daily for which it pays 21 cents per 1,000 gallons. The rate was reduced from 25 cents, three or four years ago as a result of strong representations made to the Railway Company. I do not know how serious the situation is as regards the probability of the river going dry this winter due to the exceptionally dry summer and autumn and the absence of any storage since the dam was washed away last spring. The Department of Indian Affairs probably are not justified in taking the risk of a water shortage if their assistance will ensure the completion of the dam project.

It is quite possible that the requirements of the Canadian Pacific Railway and the Department of Indian Affairs do not necessitate the extensive pondage provided by the proposed project. However, in view of all the interests involved it would appear advisable to complete the project in accordance with the suggestions outlined in Mr. Hogarth's report. Provision of a fish ladder appears unnecessary and it might be advisable to change the type of construction in view of the dam being constructed under winter conditions.

In discussing the situation with Mr. Holden, the writer suggested that in lieu of contributing a certain percentage of the cost of the dam, the Company might revise the rates now charged for water supplied the Indian School. A reduction from 21 cents to 18½ cents per thousand gallons was suggested. Mr. Holden thought he could secure the approval of Company officials for such an arrangement, provided the Company would be relieved of maintenance of the dam. It was pointed out to Mr. Holden that I was not authorized to make any such suggestion but was merely getting his views before making such a suggestion to my Director.

The average monthly water bill paid by the School is now approximately $40.00 or $480.00 per year. The proposed revision would reduce the annual charge to approximately $390.00 and while the annual saving would not accrue directly to the Department of Indian Affairs, yet by adjustments in the grant made to the operators of the School, an indirect saving would be affected. This saving would warrant the Department of Indian Affairs sharing in the cost of the dam project.

The writer suggested to Mr. MacNamara that in view of the reluctance of the Canadian Pacific Railway to make any arrangements with the Town of Birtle with respect to the dam project, that an equitable arrangement might be for the Department of Indian Affairs in co-operation with the Railway, to contribute 50% of the cost of the project, up to a total cost of $4,000.00 for the project, the Province and Municipality to contribute the other 50%; one condition being that the Municipality seek no assistance from the Canadian Pacific Railway. Mr. MacNamara stated that he thought such an arrangement would ensure completion of the project. Of course it was pointed out to him that the writer had no authority to make any such arrangement but was merely ascertaining the Province's reaction to the suggestion before forwarding it to Ottawa.

The matter of control of the dam upon completion was taken up with Mr. Attwood. It was pointed out that in view of the reservoir being the source of water supply for human consumption at
the Indian School that the Department of Indian Affairs would require some control over the regulation. It was finally decided that if the project be undertaken, the Provincial Department of Health would be asked to declare the area surrounding the reservoir, a sanitary district and exercise control to safeguard the water supply.

The question of the actual construction of the dam was not discussed but it appears reasonable to assume that the Provincial Department of Public Works would accept responsibility for supervision, employing local labor from relief rolls, insofar as it is available.

The writer expects to hear within a day or so from Mr. Holden as to the views of the Canadian Pacific Railway. I appreciate the fact that I have had no authority to go as far as I have regarding suggestions made to Mr. Holden, Mr. MacNemara and Mr. Attwood. However, as pointed out in the final paragraph of your letter, prompt action on the part of all concerned is essential if the dam is to be built this year and I believe if arrangements can be completed in accordance with my suggestions, it will provide an equitable distribution of the cost.

Your obedient servant,

D. B. Gow,
Acting District Chief Engineer.

Enclos.
December 3rd, 1936.

Sir,

In reply to your letter of November 21st with reference to the proposed dam across Birdtail creek at Birtle, Manitoba, I enclose herewith a letter from Mr. Gow, dated November 27th, which describes the general situation with respect to the proposal for re-building the dam and the interests affected thereby. Mr. Gow also makes certain suggestions as to how the cost might be allocated between the interests affected. With respect to the Canadian Pacific Railway you will note that Mr. Gow expects to obtain further information as to their views on the matter.

Attached to Mr. Gow's letter there is a copy of a report by Mr. B.B. Hogarth, dated August 4th, 1936, which gives the history of the existing dam and the estimated cost of the reconstruction amounting to $4,270.00. This report was prepared for the information of the Prairie Farm Rehabilitation Committee. We had already obtained a copy of this report from Dr. E.S. Hopkins, Acting Director of the Central Experimental Farm. Dr. Hopkins explained that this report was of a confidential nature but when he was informed that a copy of it had been received from Mr. Gow as a part of his own report on the subject, he stated that there was no objection to its being transmitted to the Department of Indian Affairs.

With respect to this report Dr. Hopkins states:

"I may say that the attitude of our Department in this matter has been that since Birtle is scarcely in the real drought area and since the Prairie Farm Rehabilitation Vote was to be specifically confined to the drought area, we could not undertake this project."

With respect to the various suggestions made by Mr. Gow in his letter as to the manner in which the cost might be allocated between the interests affected, I should be glad to know if you would like us to secure further information.

Memorandum:

The Deputy Minister.

On December 5, 1936, the following telegram was sent to the Deputy Minister of Public Works, Winnipeg, Man., with reference to the construction of a dam over Birdtail River, Birtle, Man.

"Reference your telegram re Birtle dam Indian Affairs Branch will contribute one-fourth of cost of proposed dam up to a sum not exceeding one thousand dollars. If project proceeded with assume construction will be done under supervision of Provincial Engineers."

An amount of $1,000 was accordingly encumbered from the Special Supplementary Estimates. On December 9 the department communicated with the Deputy Minister of Public Works asking to be informed as to what action would be taken by his department in this matter. He replied that the question was under consideration by the Town and when a decision was reached he would communicate further with this department. No further word was received, and the funds provided lapsed on March 31st.

On May 13th of this year a letter was received from the Secretary-Treasurer of the Town of Birtle advising that the gate had been completed and that the work would be finished in a couple of weeks, and requesting that an accountable cheque be sent to him from the funds which this branch had promised, namely one-fourth of the cost. A reply was directed to the Secretary-Treasurer informing him that it would not be possible to comply with his request for an advance as it would be necessary for this branch to be furnished with a statement of the total expenditure made on the work, in order that a Memorandum to Council could be prepared asking for the necessary authority to make this grant. He was also advised that we had no information as to what arrangements were finally agreed upon for the construction of this dam, and asked to furnish a report as to the work carried out, what portion of the cost was being borne by other interested parties, etc.

As you are no doubt aware no funds have been specially provided to cover this grant, it being expected that the work would be performed and paid for from last year's appropriation, and it will therefore be necessary to obtain the approval of the Acting Minister to charge the amount involved to the Special Supplementary Estimates, Vote 321.

Upon receipt of the approval of the Acting Minister and statement from the Town of Birkin as to the actual expenditure a Memorandum to Council will be prepared requesting the necessary authority to make this grant.
