The undersigned has the honour to report:

THAT in December last the Department of Mines and Resources, Indian Affairs Branch, agreed to contribute one-fourth of the cost of the construction of a dam over the Birdtail River, at Birtle, Manitoba, up to an amount of $1,000.00.

THAT the construction of the said dam is particularly advantageous to this department as the Birtle Indian Residential School obtains its water supply from the Canadian Pacific Railway Company and is accordingly dependent on the Birdtail River as its source of supply.

THAT the department would not be justified in taking the risk of a water shortage at this school, and it is deemed advisable, in view of the circumstances, to contribute towards the cost of the construction of the aforementioned dam.

THAT the construction of the said dam has been completed by the Town of Birtle at a total cost of $3,600.45.

THAT funds are available in the Special Supplementary Estimates, Indian Affairs Branch, of the Department of Mines and Resources under Vote 381, 1937-38.

The undersigned has the honour to recommend that a grant of $900.00, being one-fourth of the cost, be now made to the Town of Birtle, as this department's share of the cost of the construction of the said dam.

Respectfully submitted,

Minister of Mines and Resources.

Dear Sir:

Ref: Your 106-1-10 of May 20th, Ledoux Children.

The mother of these children was a Miss Menitoken, a member of the Muskeg Lake Band, Carlton Agency. She has two brothers, Bernard and Basil, still living on that Reserve. Miss Menitoken met a man by the name of Lafontaine, to whom she was legally married. They lived together only for a few months. Lafontaine was either a white man or a half-breed. He was not an Indian and was not a member of any Band.

After separating from Lafontaine, she ran wild for a few years, and then went to live with Isadore Ledoux, with whom she has lived the greater part of the time since, and, I am informed, is living with him today.

The mother of these children has not lived on the Reserve since marrying Lafontaine, and had no children prior to her marriage. Isadore Ledoux is a member of the Muskeg Lake Band, but has not lived on the Reserve for years. He was legally married to a Miss Lafonde, who left him owing to family difficulties and is, I understand, living with his brother on Muskeg Lake Reserve.

The mother, I believe, is and always has been an R.C. The father was an R.C. and tried last Fall to have his children admitted to the R.C. School at Duck Lake, but was refused by the Principal on the grounds that the children were not eligible. Ledoux, I understand, now claims he has been a Presbyterian for the last two years.

I have delayed replying to this letter in order to interview Mr. Bell, Clerk, Battleford Agency, who was formerly in the Carlton Agency, and knew all about these people. I trust this information is what you required.

Yours truly,

Thos. Robertson,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Saskatchewan.

REGINA, SASK., Aug. 15, 1938.

Dear Sir:

Ref: Your 106-1-10 of August 6th,
Ledoux Children.

Insofar as I can ascertain, the following are the facts concerning these children:

They are illegitimate. Their mother is and always has been a Roman Catholic. Ledoux, who claims to be the father of the children, has always been considered a Roman Catholic, although he claims he became a Presbyterian two years ago. Last Fall, however, he attempted to have these children admitted to the Roman Catholic School at Duck Lake, which action inclines me to believe that he is only changing his religion for the purpose of getting the children into an Indian School.

If my understanding is correct that illegitimate children belong to the mother and take her religion, then these children are without question Roman Catholics. If, on the other hand, the father's wishes are to receive consideration, I feel that we would not be justified in accepting his statement that he became a Presbyterian two years ago, due to the fact that last Fall he applied to have these children admitted to a Roman Catholic School.

I would therefore recommend that if these children are admitted, it be under Roman Catholic denomination.

Yours truly,

Thos. Robertson,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Saskatchewan.

Reverend Sir:

For some months past the Department has been giving very careful consideration to the request which was received for the education of the two children of Isadore Ledoux in an Indian Residential School.

It has finally been decided that these children are Indians and are, therefore, eligible for admission to an Indian Residential School.

When their status in this regard was finally settled further careful consideration was given to the religious auspices under which they should be educated. Recently the following information was received from Inspector Robertson:

"They are illegitimate. Their mother is and always has been a Roman Catholic. Ledoux, who claims to be the father of the children, has always been considered a Roman Catholic, although he claims he became a Presbyterian two years ago. Last fall, however, he attempted to have these children admitted to the Roman Catholic School at Duck Lake, which action inclines me to believe that he is only changing his religion for the purpose of getting the children into an Indian School.

"If my understanding is correct that illegitimate children belong to the mother and take her religion, then these children are without question Roman Catholics. If, on the other hand, the father's wishes are to receive consideration, I feel that we would not be justified in accepting his statement that he became a Presbyterian two years ago, due to the fact that last fall he applied to have these children admitted to a Roman Catholic School."

Principal, Birtle Residential School,
Birtle, Man.
"I would therefore recommend that if these children are admitted, it be under Roman Catholic denomination."

Lockhart, principal of the Birtle Indian School, to the effect that the above named boy had left the school and he was unable to locate him although he had made several attempts to do so, and requested this detachment endeavour to find the lad, whom he claimed had returned to his home on the Waywayseecappo Indian Reserve.

(2) (8-9-38)
On the A.M. of this date I left per pol. car code # 1554 and patrolled to the reserve in question and although I enquired at several places on the reserve I was unable to locate this boy, Mrs. Annie Buffalo informing me that when she saw my car he went into the bush.

(3) I returned to the detachment at noon the same date, and at 7.30 P.M. this same date I left again per pol. car code # 1554 and in the late P.M. in company with H. Nield, Farm Instructor on the reserve, I again endeavoured to locate Cloud but he was nowhere to be found.

(9-9-38)

(4) At noon this date a telephone message was received at this office from Mr. Graham, grain buyer of the Birdtail siding, who informed me that he was speaking on behalf of Sarah Cloud, Indian and Mother of the captionedly noted, and that Harry Cloud was at the present time with his mother at A. Best's place 1 mile West of the Birdtail siding.

(5) On the P.M. of same date I again left per pol. car code # 1554 and patrolled to Mr. Best's place where the boy was located and taken into custody.

(6) I left immediately after locating the lad and escorted him to Birtle where he was handed over to the authorities of the Indian School at that point and a body receipt obtained for same.

CONCLUDED.

Mr. Lockhart has asked me to write a note of explanation as to why these children with Roman Catholic guardians are seeking admission to the Birtle Indian School.

They are the children of Rosie Catagas by a first husband who was a member of the Rolling River Presbyterian Church. There are two daughters of his by a former marriage already pupils in the school, and it is the desire of the mother that these children of Philliss should be educated in the same school and be brought up in the same religious faith as their step-sisters and their own father. Dear Mr. Ostrander,

I am enclosing application forms signed by Mrs. Alex Categas re Mrs. Categas' two children, Roy and Charity, for whom they desire admission to the Birtle Indian Residential School. Also Miss Buckley's letter giving her explanation of the situation.

The father of these children whom Miss Buckley speaks of as Phillip was Phillip Anderson who died at O.K. recently.

I ought add that at present we have a little over the number in residence for which we require a grant, but not over the capacity of the school building. 19-5-39.

1. Relative to the above I have to report at 11:15 P.M. this date I received a phone call from Mr. Lochart, Superintendent of the Birtle Indian Residential School, to the effect that the above named Indian boy had run away from the school on the evening of 18-5-39. Mr. Lochart informed me that Mr. J.G. Hough, Boys Superintendent of the School had been out around the country looking for him and could not find him. Mr. Lochart also stated that this boy came from the Waynaysegoop Reserve. I.R. Speers was informed and as there was a Pow-Wow this night at the home of this boy's mother on the Reserve, he thought that the boy might be there and could be caught. Mr. Lochart informed me that he had communicated with Rossburn Det. and was informed that Capt. Speers was away on other duties at this time. Arrangements were made to meet Mr. J.G. Hough at Angusville when he would show me the way to the home of Mrs. Mentuk on the Reserve.

2. At 11:30 P.M., same date, I patrolled from Russell to Angusville, via R.C.1663, where I met Mr. J.G. Hough, and some other Indian boys from the Birtle School, and together we patrolled to the Waynaysegoop Reserve. While driving through the reserve to the home of Mrs. Mentuk, and while we came to the home of Young Shingoose, it was observed that the Pow-Wow was being held at this home. On entering the home of Shingoose where the Pow-Wow was in progress, and from enquiries made I was reliably informed that the above named boy had been at the Pow-Wow, and had left about fifteen minutes previous to our arrival.

3. We continued to the home of Mrs. Mentuk and found that the house was padlocked. We continued around other homes where we thought this boy might be located, but without results.

4. It was quite obvious to the writer that this boy on seeing the car coming, ran out into the bush and hid until our departure, and would remain on the alert for the remainder of the night.

5. Return patrol was made to Angusville where Mr. J.G. Hough and the Indian boys transferred to their own car, and the writer returned to Russell, arriving at det. at 3:15 A.M. 20-5-39. Mr. Hough is returning to the home of the above named boy in the early hours of 22-5-39, when it is thought that he will be at home and asleep. He is arranging with Capt. Speers to accompany him on this trip.

6. In view of the above this file will be considered closed at this det. and handed over to det. concerned.

The R.C.M.P. have since broadcast a description of the boys from Regina by radio, and have asked all detachments to be on the look-out for them, but so far no trace of the boys has been found.

She made the approach herself, and then having satisfied myself as to her sincerity she was duly received. She is now on the Reserve with her grandparents, who are protestants and who cared for her for some years before her admission to our School, and with whom she spent her holidays from year to year. Reverend Sir:

Dr. Johnston has passed on to me a letter addressed by you to the Department, dated Birtle, Manitoba, September 21, 1939.

In this letter you express surprise that a pupil, named Jean Mecas, enrolled at your school, was discharged with departmental approval at the end of the last academic year.

The records here indicate that this action was taken in response to a request contained in a letter received by the Department from Indian Agent A. G. Smith and dated Birtle, Man., April 28, 1939. In this letter the Indian Agent states:

"Donald Mecas, No. 223 of the Waywaysecongo Band, does not wish the education of his child to be continued under Protestant auspices. This man is a Roman Catholic. His daughter is Jean Mecas, Register No. 0631, age 15 years, at present a pupil in the Birtle Residential School".

In view of a number of disputes that had arisen in respect to the religious status of Indian pupils and particularly certain Indian pupils in attendance at Indian residential schools, the Department of Indian Affairs secured from the Department of Justice a ruling in respect to the matter, on the 23rd day of December, 1922.

This ruling, in part, reads as follows:

"A Protestant child is one born of Protestant parents or one whose father or widowed mother has decided to have him or her educated in a Protestant school or a school conducted under Protestant auspices. A Roman Catholic child is one born of Catholic parents or one whose father or widowed mother has decided to have him or her educated in a Roman Catholic school or a school conducted under Roman Catholic auspices".

The records here indicate that this ruling was submitted to representatives of all the churches cooperating with the Department of Indian Affairs in educational effort at that time and was accepted by them as fair and reasonable in view of all the circumstances. It is just possible, however, that you may not have received a copy of this ruling.

Yours truly,

Dear Sir:

This will acknowledge receipt of your letter No.106-1-10 of September 13th, with reference to the request of Francis Tanner of the Waywayseecappo Band to have his children removed from the Birtle School and placed in a Roman Catholic School.

Francis Tanner states that he always has been a Roman Catholic. This may be true though both Tanner and his wife were pupils in the Birtle School years ago. Tanner states that he did not know that he gave his religion as Presbyterian in the application for admission form, but I do not believe that statement, as he desired to have his children in the nearest school to the Reserve, and on that account gave his religion as Presbyterian.

Since the Roman Catholics built a church on the Waywayseecappo Reserve two years ago, several Indians who passed as Presbyterians are now Roman Catholics.

Many years ago the Roman Catholics had a church on this Reserve, then for years they had no regular services, with the result that some of the original Roman Catholics became recognised as Presbyterians, now many of these people are returning to their original faith, with the result that we really do not know what religion they belong to, and in some cases they do not know themselves.

About a month ago a Roman Catholic woman was baptized as a Presbyterian, maybe as a matter of convenience to get her child into the Birtle School, or she may be quite genuine in her desire to become a Presbyterian. The child will be a pupil in Birtle School, and I could certainly not refuse to sign the application on the grounds that the Mother was a Roman Catholic before becoming a Presbyterian.

Dear Sir,

Maurice Bone, a Cree student from Birtle Indian Residential School, was admitted on August 24, 1931. His father, James Bone, gave Maurice's age as seven years. The Baptismal Records say he was born June 25, 1924. He was therefore fifteen years old on July 25, 1939. His state of education at the time of entrance was illiterate. During his eight years in school, he has been in accordance with the regulations of the Department, attended classes, and attended classes during the school year. His parents have not returned him to school since the holiday season. They want him discharged.

I cannot see any reason why Maurice should not be in school until he is sixteen years of age. His parents have no need of him at home for their support.

Your Agent, Mr. A. J. Smith, has told me that I am not aware that Maurice or his family have been absent from the Reserve for several days, and that during that time four draft horses, given to them by yourself, were turned loose on the Reserve and fell harness locked up. I put this at a time when the horses should have been at work.

May I hear from you at your earliest convenience.

Dear Sir:

I am enclosing herewith a letter from the Rev. E.H. Lockhart regarding Maurice Bone, a pupil in the Birtle Residential School from the Keeseekowenin Reserve.

The parents of this boy are very reluctant to let him return to school, owing to some trifling trouble the boy's mother had with Mrs. Lockhart, the Matron of the School, when she last visited there. James Bone, the boy's father, is fairly industrious, and Mrs. Bone is a splendid worker; in fact, the family is the best we have on the Keeseekowenin Reserve at the present time. This boy is their only child, and they are naturally anxious to have him at home, especially as they have some cattle which will give him some work to do. Under the circumstances I do not think it advisable to bring the boy back by force, and therefore recommend his discharge.

I urgently request that all these pupils be continued in school.
It is a great pity that any of their children—boys or girls—go at the tender age of sixteen years into the environment of the reserve, scores and scores of visitors to our Indian Residential schools say what a pity they ever go back to that life on the Reserve.
Can you not get a happy Lord (you will understand what I mean) for each Reserve and develop an industry or Industrial farming etc., where Indians will be employed at certain wages and under certain definite conditions of living? They would often do many times as much work as they are now doing and Satan who finds the work for idle hands to do might begin to breed bankruptcy in his business.
Indians have cut and sold wood to me, and I know that if I were given a market to them and you gave them their right of it they would very soon strip the Reserve of all timber. Knowing that they would get less price per cord as soon as cut as the remainder when they had delivered the wood to me.
And remember that wood-cutting is one of the hardest kind of manual labor of the present day.

Dear Sir,

I have your letter 106-1-10 dated January 2nd, and I am at a loss to know what is best to do in connection with these religious problems.

This child was admitted to Pine Creek School in 1938 and apparently at that time Alex Meccas, the father, was a Catholic. In October of the past year, I am advised by the Rev. AGENCY REPORT ON BIRTLE AGENCY FOR MONTH OF APRIL 1940.

All the reserves have been visited and supervision of seeding operations has been carried out by the Farming Instructor, Clerk and myself. Three Indians were tried by me at Erickson under Sec. 135 of the Indian Act, and were sentenced to 14 and 21 days imprisonment; as the offence nearly cost one of them his life, I did not think that a fine was sufficient punishment. We could not find out who supplied the liquor. Five boys ran away from the residential school during the month, but all returned safely of their own accord.

A. G. Smith,
Indian Agent.

Oct. 14th, 1941.

Alfred McQUABEC, 'et al', Rossburn Manitoba.
Truants from Birtle Indian School.

(Rossburn Det. Case)

(9-10-41)

On the late P.M. of this date a telephone message was received at this office from the Rev. Lockhart, Principal of the above school, to the effect that Alfred McQuabec had not reported to the school as yet for this term and Mr. Lockhart figured that the father, Peter McQuabec was not allowing him to go to school this fall, also that his younger brother, James McQuabec, had left the school at noon this date and had not returned and it was thought both boys were on the reserve close to this point; Mr. Lockhart requesting that they be located and brought to the school.

(11-10-41)

On the A.M. of this date 3/Cst. Boykowicz, left det. per. P.C. # 1948 and patrolled to the reserve in question and although he made exhaustive enquiries he was unable to locate either boy.

On the late P.M. of this date Alfred McQuabec was located in this village by 3/Cst. Boykowicz and brought to this office, his father being with him at the time, and the father was of the opinion that this lad was over 16 years of age and therefore not required to attend school this term.

A.G. Smith, Indian Agent at Birtle, was got in touch with by L.D. telephone at this time and he stated the lad was only 15 yrs. of age and therefore should be at school, however at the request of the father he was given an extra week off, in order that the father and the lad may complete a haying contract they had taken on, the father consenting to take the boy down at the end of the week.

(12-10-41)

On the P.M. of this date the other lad, James McQuabec was turned over to the Indian Agent who happened to be in this village this date, the above instructions being given to the father from this office the night previous, and was escorted back to school in question by Mr. Smith, same date.

November 17th

Gentlemen,

I have been very much disturbed about my children, and so had trouble with the Indian agent concerning them.

I understand that if a child is not quite healthy he can not enter School, and if there were healthy, they should go to School when they are old enough.

I have a boy who has been troubled with eczema on his face ever since he was a very small fellow, and I have had three doctors treating him ever since he first had it, but they cannot cure him.

So as I know how bad it affects him I did not send him.
School in the first place.

But the Indian agent was after me to send him, and so was the Principal of the School. He said they could easily cure him if he were in school, even after what the doctors had done for him, and that he was to get constant treatment and that he would use the best and mildest soap they could give him.

Well I sent him to school hoping they may be able to cure him; he got a few treatments when he first entered school & then he was even more neglected than he ever was at home.

He told me even uses scrubbing soap to wash his face except when his mother buys him soap, which he keeps in his pocket.

And he has come home for his holidays two summers with his face full of sores. He could
Hardly open his eyes, and his lips was so swollen he can not open his mouth to enjoy a good meal.

What was worse he did not have as much as a salve to put on his face, on both times. It would have made me feel better if he had, as we should think they were at least doing something to ease his pain.

There is a nurse right in the school, and the doctor goes up often but when I sent my girl back to school in August 1940 I told the Principal I wasn't sending the boy back & told him why, well they got the doctor up & we could see that he had never seen the boy's face while in school.

I have another little boy who has not been in school yet. This boy catches cold very easily and so he has had pneumonia.
Three times already.

I have told the Indian agent all this in a letter before when he told me to put the boys in school.

But last week he came up to me and said I was to take the boys to school this week.

Well I told him I wouldn't. He asked why, and I had already told him why, and he said he would send the police after them.

I know they have to go to school but they are my children and I want some respect shown to me regarding them.

I shall send the little boy in as soon I am positive that he can take real good care of himself.

I have seen the boys in the school without caps, without shoelaces, snow in their boots, mittens wet & shrunken so.
small they cannot fit, and yet sliding on the hill in winter shivering & faces so blue with cold.

How can I send my boy there when he wouldn't be watched whether his feet are dry or if he had good mitts & shalocks. For even at home where his mother watches these things closely, he catches colds.

And as I said before I shall send him just as soon as he can take care of himself even at his play he shall go to school.

And the older boy will be sixteen years old coming May 8th.

If there is a law in the Indian affairs for policemen to come & take children for their fathers & put them in school I shall be very pleased to know.

And if so why doesn't the agent get after the parents of the other children as well as me.
It seems to be after my boys more than the other children; he does not help me feed them. I provide for my own family. And I have never used any of the government things to help me along too.

There were quite a lot of cattle given to this reserve a few years ago and although I have a big family he did not give me one to keep, and gave them to a few with whom he is more friendly than the rest of us; they got from $5 to $10 each.

And a short while ago my wife asked if she can keep one cow, as all the children love milk, the agent told her I had no cow barn. A cow barn can be built of logs & plastered good within one week by a single man.

I've almost always had quite a lot of hay & would
have to sell most of it anyway.

The Indian agent does not treat the Indians alike; he has his favorites.

Last winter when flour was given to the Indians, 25 lbs per person, he said he was not giving any to my two boys and he didn't.

I think why he has no use for me & wouldn't treat me good is—when the tractor first started plowing on the reserve Mr Smith told me that any man who clears any land while he would like to farm, he get it plowed for them, so I cleared up a bit of land too in the valley and there was a piece of land along side which I wanted plowed along with my clearing, and they were fencing a cattle pasture & they wanted to fence right through where I wanted my plowing done. So I told not to fence it as I wanted that land.
Well they didn't fence it, but at the same time I was told I would not get my land plowed. The agent said so himself so I also stopped clearing as I knew I wouldn't get it plowed anyway although I had worked hard week clearing that land.

They had already a cattle pasture big enough for several hundred cattle, besides there are other places that would make good cattle pasture but not farming.

The agent has his favorites that is why I hear he'd come upon them, house full of drunk but let's them go & when he found one drunk in town he put him in the car & brought him home.

I suppose if I was a drunke drunkard or a jail bird he'd have some respect for me.

I have never in my life been in jail nor even been in court.
I've always been a quick man
I hate to have trouble with the
Indian agent nor anyone else.
But when he said he'd send
the policeman after my toys
I couldn't stand it.

Every parent's child is dear to
them even the birds & beasts.
So if he is sending the police
I am afraid we are going to
have more & bigger trouble.

One thing more—The staff in
the school are not always very
kind to the children, that is why
they are always running away from
the school; the Indian children
have feelings are well as any other.
So when mistreated they think
they must get away from the un-
kind people without stopping to
think of dangers they might
come across on the way.
I have seen the toys doing
a lot of running away lately.
I shall be very pleased.
if you would kindly help me in my troubles.

I should like very much if you could write to me personally and let me know what I should do to keep out of all this trouble. And please tell the agent all I said. He is - A. G. Smith

1st December 1941

Dear Sir:

Your letter No. 106-1-10 of November 24th, has been received, and also the enclosed letter from Sam Bohpa of the Bird Tail Sioux Band to the Department.

This man does not cause any trouble, but will not send his two boys to school although I have given him every chance to do so. One boy is troubled with eczema and was treated for it at school. As you are no doubt aware this disease is very troublesome, and will break out after it appears to be cured. That is the case with one of his boys. They should not miss the chance of an education however on account of this trouble as it is not infectious. The other boy has had pneumonia two or three times and may not be strong enough to attend school, but that is for the Doctor to say when he examines him. Dr. Edwards the Medical Officer for the school knows the boy well and has treated him for Pneumonia.

During Inspector Hamilton's recent visit to that Reserve, he said these boys should be in school, and suggested that I prosecute the Father under Sec. 10 Para. 4 of the Indian Act, if he would not send them, and I intend to do so, unless you instruct me not to.

Sam Bohpa is not much of a worker and the children are not very well provided for at home. He is a fair trapper, but will never make a Farmer hence my refusal to break land for him or give him cattle.

Regarding Bohpa's complaint about the clothing that the children wear at school. Two or three years ago I think that he had every right to make that complaint but now the children are clad much better. Your records will show that the school children have been very healthy in recent years, and Pneumonia is much more prevalent on the Reserves than in the school.

Bohpa claims that I have favourites on the Reserve. The Indians are of course bound to think that
as the farming Indians do receive more help than the others in many ways. Bohpa did receive horses and other help from the Department years ago to help him to start farming, but it was a waste of effort, as he would never make a farmer.

I informed Bohpa that his boys would have to attend school, but if he did not desire to send them to Birtle School, I would take the matter up with the Department and see if they could be admitted to Cecilia Jeffrey's School at Kenora. Of course he would not desire to send them so far from home.

During the last six years no children in this Agency have been forced to attend school, as I hate to use compulsion. The children do belong to the parents, and as a parent I would strongly object to being forced to send my children to a boarding school by the Government. However due to my leniency there are several children of school age on the Reserve, and unless we take a firm stand in some cases, it will become worse, and it will be hard to obtain sufficient pupils for the schools.

At present there are more pupils in the Birtle School than they are actually paid grant for, but they are willing to take more in.

I would suggest that you write to Bohpa, informing him that his children have to attend school, if physically fit, according to the provisions of the Indian Act. If that is done I do not think any further compulsion will be necessary.

In the meantime I will take no further action, until I hear from you.

Yours truly,

A.G. Smith
Indian Agent

Dear Sir:

Re: Leo Goodvoice.

The Leo Goodvoice you have reference to was in attendance at this school for several years and proved to be a very desirable type of lad. He was conscientious about his work, both in the classroom and outside. He applied himself diligently to anything he undertook. He is the type of fellow who, given the opportunity under proper guidance, could go to great lengths as an influence for the betterment of his people.

I would like to see Leo re-instated, if possible at this school for another year or two, as I think he has great promise.

Trusting that this is the information that you desire, and that it will help you to arrive at a decision, I remain,

Yours truly,

Truancy from Birtle Indian School, Manitoba.

30-1-42.

1. At 11.45pm of this date a phone call was received at this office from A.SMITH, Indian Agent, Birtle, Manitoba, stating that six juveniles had run away on 29-1-42 from the Lizard Point I.R. near Rosseburn, Man. Among them were two youths from the Lizard Point I.R. near Rosseburn, Man. namely Harry CLOUD, age 16 yrs, and Jimmy MENTUK, age 15 yrs. They had left Birtle in the P.M. of 29-1-42, and were allegedly seen leaving a freight train near Gordon, 29-1-42, at Solsgirth, Manitoba. Mr. SMITH believed that it was likely the youths might have walked from Solsgirth to their homes on the Lizard Point I.R. and would possibly be at home by this time, he requested that their homes be checked this afternoon if possible and to arrest the youths if found and then advise the Agency and they would arrange transportation. The other four youths were from another Reserve but it was thought they might also accompany CLOUD and MENTUK.

2. The writer patrolled per hired livery team and cutter, roads being impassable for police transport to the Lizard Point I.R. and there carefully checked and searched at the homes of Harry CLOUD and Jimmy MENTUK, without result, no damage was done during these searches, and it was with the permission of the parents, further patrol and check of various other relatives failed to reveal any trace of the missing youths, and the patrol checked at the premises of Howard NIELD the overseer and he advised a close watch would be kept for the youths. The patrol returned to detachment at 5.00pm, 30-1-42.

3. On return to detachment and during the absence of the writer, 2/Oct. BOYKO, I.C., advised that a further phone call from A.SMITH agent Birtle, Man., had advised the youths had been located at Brodenbury, Sask.

4. Extra copy this report for the information of the Department concerned.

1. With reference to the above, please be advised that at 9:00 AM this date, telephonic communication was received from Cst. McConnell, of Yorkton Det., to the effect that three Indian students had run away from the Indian school at Birtle Manitoba, and the principal was anxious to have them located, and detained. Youths were as follows:
   Dennis KITCHENOMIA - Aged 17.
   Ernest KITCHENOMIA - Aged 14.
   Edward BOE - Aged 16.

2. On receipt of the above information, J.L. BRYANT, Polly Indian Agent was advised, and discreet enquiries were made among reliable Indians, who promised to advise this detachment, should the youths appear on the reserves in this vicinity.

3. At 5:00 PM this date, advice was received from J.L. BRYANT, Indian Agent that the youths had arrived on the Cote Indian Reserve this PM, and were at present located at the home of Mr. KITCHENOMIA, a relative. Advice to this effect was conveyed to A.M. KANEK, Principal of the Birtle Indian school, who requested that the youths be picked up by the police, and detained until train time this late PM, and then placed on the east bound train with single tickets to Roblin, at which point, he would arrange to meet them.

4. The writer with Cst. Fontaine, immediately patrolled via Pol/Car Code 8260 from Kamsack to the Cote Indian reserve, where Ernest KITCHENOMIA and Edward BOE were located at once. Enquiries, concerning Dennis KITCHENOMIA revealed that he had run away at the same time as the rest, but had remained in Saskatoon, with the intention of joining the Prince Albert Volunteers. J.L. BRYANT, Indian Agent provided the writer with two requisitions, to present when obtaining tickets, for the three Indian juveniles, which would cover a seating of forty cents in each case. After making exhaustive enquiries, which indicated that Dennis KITCHENOMIA was not on the reserve, patrol returned to Kamsack at 8:30 PM. The two lads promised to remain on the train, until it reached Roblin, Man., and the writer put them on the east bound train at 9:30 PM, after providing them with single tickets to that point.

5. I might state further in regard to Dennis KITCHENOMIA, as this lad is 17, it appears that little can be done if he does not wish to return to school. Dear Sir:

I beg to submit the following report for the month of May:

GENERAL:

Annuity was paid during the month, and meetings held on the different Reserves after the payment. Complaints were few and mostly trivial. The Indians are planting more gardens, and so far prospects for the root crop, which concerns them most, are good. The epidemic of truancy at the Residential School has apparently stopped. Dear Sir:

Re: Children of Francis Tanner

I have for acknowledgment your letter of the 28th instant and also a declaration made by Francis Tanner and his wife of the Waywayseecappo Band renouncing their adherence to the Roman Catholic Church and desiring that their children be educated at the Birtle Residential School.

It is scarcely necessary to state that everything possible should be done by our officials to discourage the transfer of pupils from one denominational school to another. These transfers have a tendency to interrupt their studies and must result in a great deal of perplexity and confusion to the pupils themselves. The recommendation made by you in the second last paragraph of your communication is perhaps the best arrangement we can make in view of all the circumstances. If you could assure us, however, that there is a day school within easy reach of these people the Department is of the opinion that these children should be discharged from the Sandy Bay School and encouraged to attend a day school. If no day school is available, however, your recommendation that the senior pupils be permitted to complete their education at Sandy Bay and that the younger children be enrolled in due course at Birtle is acceptable to the Department and approved.

Yours truly,

Indian Agent,

Ottawa,
September 9, 1942.

Dear Sir:

Re: Mary Anne Cook, No. 0376,
Birtle Residential School.

I desire to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 3rd instant and to state that the Department cannot, with the limited information at our disposal, authorize the enrolment of the above-noted pupil at the Sandy Bay Residential School.

It appears that there is, at the present time, a religious war on the Waywayseecappo Reserve and keen competition between those engaged in missionary effort amongst this particular band of Indians. In view of this fact, I think it might be well if you had an understanding with the Principals of the Birtle and Sandy Bay Residential Schools that no pupils would be enrolled at either school, or transferred from one school to the other, without your consent and Departmental approval. In the case of this particular girl, the Principal of the Sandy Bay School should be notified of the Department's decision. My personal opinion is that this girl should be returned to her parents on the reserve until her case is very carefully reviewed by you and until a recommendation in respect to the school at which she should be enrolled is sent forward by you to the Department. This decision should be sent forward to the Principal of the Sandy Bay School.

Yours truly,

Mr. A.G. Smith,
Indian Agent,
Birtle, Man.

Dear Dr. Johnston,

Re. children of Francis Tanner, Waywayseecappo Reserve,
Rossburn, Manitoba.

During the period of my visit to this Reserve in the month
of August the missionary arranged for me to have an interview
with one of the Indians on the Reserve, Francis Tanner, by
name. In the course of the interview it developed that he
and his wife had been Roman Catholics, but that now he wished
to abjure his faith in that Church and wished to connect him-
self with the Presbyterian Mission on the Reserve. I had
quite a lengthy conversation with the Indian and his wife and
tried to explain to them the characteristic principles of the
Reformed Faith. At the conclusion of our talk he signed an
adjuration of his faith in the Roman Catholic Church, and in-
dicated at the same time his desire that his children should
now attend the school at Birtle. A copy of this was left
with the Indian Agent, at Birtle, with the request that it be
forwarded to Ottawa.

I am enclosing a letter received from Mr. H. Crump, our mission-
ary on the Reserve, whose letter I laid before the Executive.
It would seem from this letter that the Roman Catholics have no
difficulty in getting children who had been attending the Birtle
school to go to their school if the parents make such a request.

The missionary told me about this Kathleen Cook. There was no
other reason for the change, as far as I could learn, but what
is stated in Mr. Crump's letter; but that was sufficient for her
to be taken to Sandy Bay School.

I hope you may be able to do something in Ottawa about this.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Mr. Hamilton:

I am sending forward herewith copies of correspondence relating to the education of the children of one Francis Tanner, of the Waywayseecappo Reserve.

It is regretted by the officials here that we have to bring this matter to your attention in a period when the time at your disposal must of necessity be somewhat limited. However, the tendency on the part of certain Indian families to transfer their children from a school of one denomination to a school operated under the auspices of another has in our judgment reached somewhat serious proportions. We feel that everything humanly possible should be done to discourage this tendency. It is difficult to think of anything more cruel than the act of taking children from a school where they have become acquainted with their teachers and with their associates and putting them into a school where everything is strange and where the general environment may differ radically from the one to which they have become accustomed.

It will be necessary for you to visit the Waywayseecappo Reserve and to interview Francis Tanner and his wife. You will note the decision reached by the Department on the recommendation of the Indian Agent, that four of these children be left at Sandy Bay and four be enrolled at Birtle. This decision has been very vigorously challenged by representatives of the Presbyterian Church who called at my office a few days ago. Indeed there is in the church an extreme element who are anxious, even at this date, to make a public issue of the matter. Dr. Johnston and Dr. Cameron appear to be somewhat reasonable, however, and are of the opinion that even at this stage the matter can be settled somewhat amicably. Both these clergymen are very indignant at the enrolment of one, Mary Anne Cook, No. 0378, at the Sandy Bay School, which action, they contend, was taken without the knowledge or consent of the Indian agent. The correspondence relating to this pupil is also sent forward for your guidance.

We are anxious that you should secure all the evidence that may be available in respect to the religious status of Francis Tanner at this time. Dr. Johnston contends that the Tanners have always been Protestants and that Francis Tanner himself was educated at the Birtle school. His contention is that Tanner has become a Presbyterian as the result of individual research and investigation and is fairly intelligent. We should like to have your comments on these statements. If you are satisfied that the Tanner family have indeed in truth become

Mr. A. G. Hamilton,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
558 Dominion Public Building,
Winnipeg, Manitoba.
Presbyterians, the Department would be disposed to have all the children returned to Birtle. The representatives of the Presbyterian Church are bitterly opposed to the division of the family and stated that under no consideration would they permit the family to remain divided.

I should like to have a report from you, stating to what extent recruiting is permitted on the reserves in the Birtle Agency without the knowledge and consent of the agent. Has it been the practice for representatives of the churches to go on to a reserve and recruit pupils without the consent of the agent or the approval of the Department? The fact that a pupil may be taken into a school as a non-grant-earning pupil does not in my judgment render this practice in any sense more tolerable. I would rather think that Indians, although they are wards of the Government, have still some rights in a nation which at this date is engaged in a war for freedom.

You are probably aware that the revision of the Indian Act is at the present time under consideration. I am anxious to know if you could, with your experience, suggest amendments to the Act that would help us to correct certain abuses, particularly the interchange of pupils at our residential schools. I have felt for some time, and I am still of the opinion that these disputes cannot be properly decided by a court of competent jurisdiction. I do not consider it fair to the officials here or to our officials in the field that we should be called upon from time to time to decide on the religious status of a particular Indian family. We have seldom at our disposal in these cases the information necessary to reach a sound conclusion. I have promised the representatives of the Presbyterian Church that this investigation would be undertaken and completed by you at the earliest possible date.

Yours very truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Dear Sir,

Re: Education of Tanner children, Nawayasgagano Reserve, Birtle Agency

As requested in your letter dated September 30th, 1942, I investigated carefully concerning this case and would report my findings as follows:

I considered it advisable to interview as well as Francis Tanner and his wife, his two brothers, his sister, and his mother and father. I found Basil Tanner, the father, was raised a Catholic. He claims to have spent about ten years in the Lebret School, and after that one year in the old Regina School. His wife, a Sturgeon, was always a Presbyterian.

This couple had three sons and a daughter, and all were educated at the Birtle Indian Residential School. The old man claimed he was not concerned as to which religion they accepted but he did want them educated.

The daughter, Mrs. Eli Bunn, belongs to the United Church of Canada.

John Tanner states he is a Presbyterian and was married by the Rev. Mr. Lockhart. His wife stated she was a Roman Catholic; but wanted her daughter educated at Birtle.

Mr. and Mrs. Edward Tanner stated they were married by the Priest but about one year ago he and his family joined the Presbyterian Church.

Mr. and Mrs. Francis Tanner were married by the Presbyterian minister, Mr. Wilson. As pointed out above, Francis was educated at Birtle and he attended the Presbyterian Church until the Catholic Church was rebuilt about eight years ago. His wife prior to her marriage was a Ben girl from the Bird Tail Sioux Reserve. Her people are Presbyterians.

I understand from Francis and his wife that for two years the visiting Priest tried to get his children for Sandy Bay School. According to Tanner, he was told the children would be better cared for and better educated. Tanner claims that after hearing this for about two years he believed such to be the case; and in order to obtain it for his children he joined the Roman Catholic Church. Now after having his children in the school for some time he finds they are not learning any better - do not receive any better treatment, and above all they are further from home and he cannot see them during the year. In view of this he feels he has made a mistake and so now wants the children back in the Birtle School. As before, he knows he cannot do this and remain a Catholic and so he stated he was finished with the Roman Catholic religion and told the Priest. He has now renewed his connection with the Presbyterian Church. I asked Francis how he could satisfy himself in making changes from one church to another. He answered - "There is no difference anyway. Mr. Crump and the Priest preach just the same way", and that his main concern was to get the best for the children.

Now as to whether the Tanner have now become Presbyterians in sincerity and truth. This, I think, is already answered and in my opinion he did not leave the Presbyterian Faith to join the Catholic Church and later leave the Catholic Faith to join the Presbyterian because of any deep religious convictions; but merely for the purpose of getting his children accepted at the different schools. Even now he states there is no difference and that Mr. Crump and the Priest preach the same. This statement, I am sure, shows how little he truly understands as far as sincere and abiding religious teaching is concerned.

As to the extent of recruiting on reserves by representatives of different churches, I have already stated what information Tanner gave me; namely, that the Rev. Father carried on his campaign for two years before Tanner finally consented. We have no way of knowing what any minister or clergyman talks about when visiting on the reserves. He may be teaching religion, or recruiting for some school, or both; and no doubt both might be quite proper if the clergy would confine themselves to members of their own congregation or to Indians who do not claim allegiance to any faith.

Now as to suggestions re the revision of the Indian Act to overcome difficulties similar to the one in question; I would suggest the application forms now in use be changed and made a more solemn document. The question of Religion should be at least a Declaration, not merely a statement, and it should be declared before the Indian Agent and the Clergyman concerned; and once this declaration is made, and a pupil accepted into a school, it should remain in that school until the final discharge is granted.

Again, no pupil should be accepted into any school prior to approval by Ottawa. No principal nor anyone working for a school should be allowed to take children from a reserve unless the arrangements set down above have been carefully followed.

In closing I may say that in view of the fact that Tanner was educated at Birtle as was also his wife, and also that now he has returned to the teaching he followed while there, I have no doubt he is as much a Presbyterian as anything. He definitely stated he was finished with the Catholic religion and would not again consent to allowing his children to attend a catholic school. How deep his convictions are I do not know - how long they will last I cannot guess. I repeat again that personally I am convinced religion has no bearing - it's merely a matter of trying to obtain what he considers is the best both for him and his children.

Yours very truly,

A.G. Hamilton,
Inspector of Indian Agencies

Dear Sir:

I desire to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 13th instant and to thank you for the information contained therein.

You will be interested to learn that it is our intention, just as soon as the time at our disposal will enable us to do so, to investigate very carefully and very thoroughly the procedure not followed in recruiting Indian pupils for enrolment at residential schools.

In view of the information contained in your letter, it would seem advisable to have the Tanner children, for the time being at least, enrolled at the Birtle Residential School. Francis Tanner, however, should be definitely informed by the Indian agent that it is not the intention of the Department to transfer his children, periodically, from one residential school to another. Such transfers must of necessity result in a great deal of confusion and bewilderment to the helpless pupils and result, as well, in a great deal of bitterness and misunderstanding amongst missionaries engaged in missionary effort on the Waywayseecappo Reserve.

I am sending forward a copy of this letter to Indian Agent Smith, for his information.

Yours truly,

June 16, 1945.

Dear Miss Lang:

I am in receipt of a report from the R.C.M.P. with reference to the theft of a bicycle by Lloyd Johnston, a pupil of the Birtle Indian Residential School. It appears that this boy was in town as late as 10 o'clock at night on May 25 and at that time he stole a bicycle. The police report further indicates that he took the bicycle to the Birtle School and apparently several of the boys rode the bicycle around the school grounds during the afternoon of Sunday, May 25. Eventually the owner of the bicycle recognized it and laid a complaint with the police.

This report is rather disturbing for two reasons:

1. It seems inadvisable to allow school pupils to be in town unattended at such a late hour in the evening.

2. It is difficult to understand how Lloyd Johnston and the other boys could ride the bicycle around the school grounds on Sunday afternoon without some member of the staff observing them and questioning them regarding the manner in which they came into possession of the machine.

I should appreciate your communicating with the Principal regarding this matter.

Yours truly,

Miss J. Florence Lang,
Indian Secretary,
Women's Missionary Society,
Presbyterian Church in Canada,
879 Lytton Blvd.,
Toronto, Ont.

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

At a recent meeting of the Rolling River Band, the Indians requested that they be allowed to have their children home for Christmas from the Birtle Residential School. They are quite willing to take them home and bring them back at their own expense, and to see that they all get back to school on time.

On account of the fact that they are not allowed to visit at the school during the winter months they are very anxious that this privilege be granted them.

Recruiting for this school is very difficult at present and I am afraid that we will have to use compulsion, though I am against this method personally.

A.G. Smith  
Indian Agent
Ottawa,
November 3, 1945.

Mr. A.G. Smith, Indian Agent, Birtle, Man.

I have your letter of the 28th ultimo, with reference to a request of the Rolling River Band to have their children allowed home on holidays at Christmas from the Birtle Residential School. Somewhat similar requests have been received from other schools in years past and the policy of the Department has always been to refuse such permission.

Practically every residential school makes arrangements for the parents to visit and see their children at some time during the Christmas holiday period. However, if children were allowed away from the school at that time there is no doubt that many complications would develop. It is almost impossible to prevent some contagious disease being brought back to the school and, as a result, there would be unnecessary suffering caused the children as well as considerable expense and effort required on the part of the school management. Taking everything into consideration the Department feels that it is very undesirable to allow children home on holidays from residential schools during the winter. As stated in the first part of this letter, favourable consideration cannot be given to this request.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

I am returning herewith the letter which you received from Thomas Hart Benn regarding his children and other matters.

Benn did bring his daughter to me in April complaining about her shoes. The shoes were in very poor condition, and I took the matter up with Mr. Webb, the Principal. Mr. Webb stated that he had had great difficulty in obtaining girls' shoes, and had some on order for months, which had not yet been delivered. He was purchasing some locally but could only get two or three pairs at a time, which of course would not go far.

Since Mr. Webb has been Principal I have had less complaints from the Indians about matters at the school than previously, and I think the children have been well fed, and considering present conditions, I am sure they have been better dressed. More care has also been taken to provide a balanced diet. Thomas Benn had a son killed in England, under circumstances which I believe are not pensionable. In any case Benn is quite fit to work and would not get any pension. Regarding his present wife's half-breed daughter, who he states the Department would not allow to attend the Birtle School, I took this matter up with the Department in February 1940, and Mr. Hoey replied as follows: "Very careful consideration has been given to the contents of your letter and the Department does not consider that these two children are eligible for admission as grant-earning pupils to an Indian Residential School." In view of Benn's attitude I would not recommend that this decision be reviewed at present, though it might be advisable to re-consider it at a later date. Benn is a real agitator and trouble maker.

Mr. A. G. Smith, Indian Agent, Birtle, Manitoba.

Re: Edna Wabash

I have for acknowledgment your letter of August 30, in which you seek information with respect to the residential school at which the above-noted pupil should be enrolled.

While it is the general policy and practice of the Department to have children placed in a residential school conducted under the same religious auspices as the father of the children, we cannot see how any good purpose would be served in sending this pupil to a Roman Catholic School, if both parents are anxious that the child should be enrolled at the Birtle Presbyterian School. It is noted also that the children of Charles Wabash have been baptized by a Presbyterian clergyman and apparently brought up in the Presbyterian faith. In our judgment, therefore, this pupil should be enrolled at the Birtle Residential School.

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

On the 17th inst., two ten-year-old boys ran away from the Birtle Residential School in the afternoon. Mr. Webb, the Principal, started after them as soon as possible by team, but could not find them. In the morning of the 18th they went into a farm house near the Lizard Point Reserve where their homes are, and both had frozen feet as they had slept in a straw stack all night. As the temperature that night was thirty below zero, it is a wonder that they are alive. Mr. Ament whose farm they went to, advised me by phone as soon as they got there, and I requested him to drive them to the Doctor at Angusville as soon as he had given them something to eat. The Doctor took them to Russell hospital by car and they are still there and will likely be in hospital for some time as the Doctor thinks some toes will have to be amputated.

So far as I can learn the boys had no particular reason to run away.

A.G. Smith  
Indian Agent
Ottawa, March 3, 1945.

Mr. A. G. Smith, Indian Agent, Birtle, Man.

I have your letter of the 27th ultimo, with reference to two pupils who have truanted from the Birtle Residential School. Please let me know the names and register numbers of the two boys. I would also like to know the approximate time they left the school and the approximate length of time which the Principal spent in searching for them. Please state also on what date you were notified by the Principal regarding their truancy. If there is any other information which you may have regarding this matter, you should forward it. Cases such as this are very liable to cause trouble or at least enquiry, and it is very important that we should have the fullest possible facts.

Philip Phelan,

I beg to refer you to your letter No.106-1-10 of the 3rd inst.regarding the two boys who ran away from the Birtle Residential School on February 17th and had their feet frozen.

The boys were Charles Mentuck, register No.355, and Wilfred Longclaws No.339, both belonging to the Lizard Point Reserve. The boys left the school between 2 p.m.and 4.30 p.m.when their absence was discovered. The Principal started to look for them as soon as they were missed which was about 4.30 p.m.He went out by car but could not get far as the side roads were blocked.Then he arranged to hire a driver and team and left for the Reserve about 7.30 p.m. He was out all night and was still searching for them on Sunday morning (the 18th inst.) when I advised him by phone to a farm near the Reserve, that the boys were found. He advised me about 7.30 p.m. that the boys were missing, before he left with the team.I phoned to Russell and to Angusville to try and send word to the parents that the boys were missing,and to get them to start searching from that end.

The boys are still in Russell hospital and will both be there for some time yet.I saw Dr Sharman at Angusville this week,who is caring for the boys,and he informed me that the boys were doing better than he expected, and he hoped that amputation might be unnecessary.Gangrene had set in on Mentucks foot,but was checked by the use of Sulpha drugs and Penicillin.Mentuck will likely have to go to Winnipeg at a later date to have some skin grafted onto his foot.I was pleased to get this information as he thought part of the foot would have to come off ten days ago.

There are children of school age on the Reserves of the Agency who should be in school, but on account of...
the danger to the children when they run away from school.
I have so far avoided compulsion by force, and do not desire
to take the responsibility of forcing the children to attend
a boarding school, unless you instruct me to do so.
I am of the opinion that a driving team should be kept at
the school during winter for use in case of truancy. The
children do not take the highways when running away and the
side roads are usually blocked for cars during winter.

Dear Mr. Hamilton:

In a letter dated February 27, Indian Agent Smith advised us that two boys had truanted from the Birtle Residential School and, as the result of exposure to cold, he was afraid at that time that it would be necessary to amputate some of their toes. For your information, I enclose copy of my letter of March 3 to Mr. Smith and also copy of his reply dated March 9.

Amplifying my letter to Mr. Smith of March 3, I feel it almost unnecessary to mention that even though it appears that every endeavour was made to locate the boys, there is frequently someone who will say that our staff has been negligent. With this in mind and in order to have very complete information on file regarding this case, it would be appreciated if you could find it possible to visit the Birtle School and interview those interested. It would also be advisable to either visit the Russell Hospital or for you to get in touch with Dr. Sharman and obtain an up-to-date report regarding the condition of these boys.

Re: Truancy Cases - Birtle School,
Dept. Letter 106-1-10, March 13th.

This report deals with Charles Mentuck, register No. 255, and Wilfred Longclaws, No. 239, both about eleven years old, and both belonging to the Waywayseecappo Reserve. These boys ran away from the Birtle Residential School between 2 p.m. and 4:30 p.m. on Saturday afternoon, February 17th. It was a clear, cold day, and the thermometer that night registered 20° below zero.

The Principal, Mr. Webb, discovered their absence at about 4:30 p.m. He made enquiries from the boys but all he could learn was that they went towards the track. He telephoned some nearby neighbors to be on the lookout and then took his car and drove to Solsgirth, where he had to leave his car. He walked some distance in the direction he expected they would go, in the hope of heading them off. He finally decided to return to Birtle and try to hire a driving team. He got back about 6 p.m., and after arranging for a team he again phoned settlers north of Birtle and also contacted Indian Agent Smith, who was at Shoal Lake. Mr. Webb left the School by team at 7:30 p.m.

In the meantime, Mr. Smith telephoned Mr. McTavish at Angusville, who lives near the reserve, and asked him to notify the Indians and to ask them to start hunting. Mr. McTavish said the Indians were nearly all at Rossburn attending a hockey game. Mr. Smith then telephoned the storekeeper at Rossburn and asked him to notify all the Indians he could. He also telephoned several farms north of Birtle and some living near the reserve.

Mr. Webb drove all night on different side roads and around straw stacks. He played out two teams of horses and with the third team landed on the reserve at 8 a.m., February 18th. One Indian was just hitching up to start out to hunt.

At about 8:30 a.m., a Mr. Ament, a farmer near the Waywayseecappo Reserve, telephoned Mr. Smith that the boys had just come to his house after sleeping in his straw stack. He said their feet were frozen and they needed medical attention. Mr. Smith requested him to phone the Doctor and to take the boys to the hospital in his covered sleigh. He also sent a message to Mr. Webb, who immediately started out again and met Mr. Ament and the boys at Angusville, and from there they proceeded to the Russell Hospital. The children were received medical care from Dr. Sharman and Dr. Shaw. I might add here that at 5 a.m. Mr. Webb was at a loss to know what was best so he telephoned the R.C.M.P. at Rossburn and requested their assistance.

The boys apparently had no specific reason for leaving. They said they wanted to go home. I might add that Wilfred Longclaws has a brother a year or two older who plays hockey with the school team. Wilfred cannot play because of a heart condition. The school team was playing on the Saturday...
afternoon against a Birtle team on the town rink, and Mr. Webb thinks Wilfred was feeling badly because he couldn't take part, so just took this way to relieve his feelings. The boys are all very fond of hockey and proud of their teams, and I have no doubt this had some bearing on the boys' decision to run away and go home.

The one boy, Charlie Mentuck, is back at school now. I examined his feet and found them entirely healed. The skin is red and blotchy on the toes and around the heel; but there is no soreness. He was wearing warm, hand-knit socks and gum rubbers, and attending class.

Wilfred is still in the hospital at Russell. I had Dr. Sharman show me his feet and was surprised to see them in such good condition. They appeared to be practically healed and the doctor is convinced that no surgery will be required unless something unforeseen happens. Wilfred stated that he was resting well and had no pain. The doctor attributes the wonderful improvement to the use of sulfa drugs and penicillin.

The distance from the school to the reserve is about nineteen miles and the boys could go east or west a mile or two before starting north; so the Department will realize how difficult a task faced anyone starting out to hunt these boys. In addition the country is partially covered with bush so that one might easily pass within a few hundred feet of the boys and never know it. In view of all the information gained I feel that both Mr. Webb and Mr. Smith did what they could and certainly no time was lost in securing medical help as soon as the boys were found.

I am convinced that "truancy" is the greatest cause of worry for any principal, especially during the winter months. I knew of no way in which it can be entirely eliminated; but more constant supervision during play hours and on Saturdays and Sundays would at least serve as a preventive. I would also recommend that the Agents and Principals be given a free hand to call on the R.C.M.P. for help. One never knows how serious a run-away can be and without doubt the police should be requested to assist. I mention the use of the police because of Departmental Circular 15-1, dated June 21st, 1943. I feel the police should be in at the beginning, not after others have failed, because that may then be too late. There is a detachment at Rossburn and one at Shoal Lake, and I feel confident that these men would be only too eager to assist, especially during the winter months. The above-mentioned circular should at least be moderated and the Agents left free to call on the police for help at any time.

A.G. Hamilton,
Inspector of Indian Agencies for Manitoba.

Mr. A.G. Smith,
Indian Agent,
Birtle, Man.

Dear Sir:

In the past this school has received grants to help defray the costs of transportation for the children to school in September and for return in June. Other schools are receiving the same now. This September twenty children were brought back to school by train from the Mistawasis Reserve west of Prince Albert at a cost of $154.00. Four children were brought down from the Round Plains Reserve near Prince Albert by automobile at a cost of $48.00. This makes a total of $202.00 as cost of transportation to bring these children to school. This amount was paid out in cash by the W.M.S. funds for the school.

I am asking that you please seek financial help from the Department of Mines and Resources to cover these expenses. When the children return next June, they will have to travel by train again.

Yours truly,

Sgd. N.M. Rusaw.
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa.

The Indians of the Waywayseecappo, Bird Tail Sioux, Keeseekoowenin, and Rolling River Bands, who have children in Birtle Residential School desire to have them home for a holiday at Christmas time. They would come to the school and get them, and promise to bring them back at the expiration of the holiday on time. I really think that they would do so, and that a short holiday at Christmas would tend to eliminate truancy during the coldest and most critical months of the year, when a child is liable to freeze to death if they run away. It would also give the school staff a chance to have a breathing spell for a few days.

The children's homes are within from 15 to 70 miles from the school, and there is no accommodation at the school to put the parents up for a night if they come to visit the children at Christmas time.

Mr. Rusaw, the Principal of the School, is in favour of a short holiday at Christmas, and I think it could be tried out for a year, and if the children did not come back as promised it could then be discontinued.

Mr. A.G. Smith, Indian Agent, Birtle, Manitoba.

I have your letter of the 3rd instant suggesting that certain pupils of the Birtle Residential School be allowed home for holidays at Christmas. You do not state for what length of time you consider they should be allowed out, but presumably it is for a week.

Several schools have tried the same experiment and while some of them at least would not admit the fact, it still remains that our experience shows that holidays at this period of the year are never advantageous to the child or the school management. Invariably many of the children come back suffering from colds and other sickness and as a result the school becomes a hospital for several weeks. Such condition certainly interferes with classroom work. We have issued circular letters in regard to this matter on several occasions and when we extended the summer holidays to a period of two full months it was definitely understood that this would obviate the necessity of granting weekend holidays or holidays at Christmas for which no authorization can be given.

My dear Walter:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 7th instant, with reference to the request of certain Indians to have their children allowed home from the Birtle Residential School for Christmas holidays.

I have considered your letter very carefully and have also reviewed with departmental officials similar requests, received from other Indian Bands, both this year and in previous years.

I find that the request to which you refer is not as simple a matter as it might appear. In the first place, if such permission were granted at Birtle, we would be obliged to extend it throughout the Dominion. If this were done, it would involve children travelling many hundreds of miles in some cases to reach home for Christmas.

In a residential school, children are well fed and special arrangements are made for their enjoyment at the Christmas season. It is generally one of the coldest times in the year, and there is little doubt in my mind that many of the children allowed home on holidays for Christmas would either not return promptly upon the expiry of their leave or would contract certain illnesses, which would not only affect themselves but would possibly be contagious.

I realize that many Indian parents are

Mr. A.G. Smith, Indian Agent,
BIRTLE, Manitoba.

We are in receipt of your letter of the 23rd ultimo with reference to the Bone children. Our records show that five of these children were regularly admitted to the Sandy Bay Residential School and attended that school until June 30, 1946. We have no record of Isabelle Violet Bone being enrolled at Sandy Bay. Cathrine Bone is shown on the June quarter return of the Sandy Bay School as pupil No. 6269.

The Principal of the Birtle Residential School had no right to accept the five children who had been attending the Sandy Bay School. If there was a bona fide change of religion on the part of the parents, this matter should have been brought to our attention and our decision given before accepting them at Birtle.

You should inform the Principal that these children should be returned to the Sandy Bay School from which they have not been discharged. They were simply allowed home for the summer holidays on the distinct understanding that they would return to the school upon the expiry of their leave.

I feel certain that the Principal of the Birtle Residential School will promptly carry out the instructions contained in this letter.

Dear Mr Waite:

Six children from the Elphinstone Indian Reserve, pupils of Sandy Bay Indian School, have been accepted at the Birtle School, without the necessary approval of the principal of the Sandy Bay School, being neither asked for or given. These children, their names and numbers being, Tobie Bone, 242; Donald Bone, 246; Murillia Bone 0240; Catharina Bone 0269; Jeanne Bone, 0270; and Isabel Bone, child of Thomas Bone; are all baptized Catholics and should return to Sandy Bay school.

The parents were emotionally upset by this sad fact and in that state of emotion were also influenced by the zeal of the resident minister. You will readily understand that the reason put forth is not sufficient to justify such procedure and which is furthermore not according to the provisions of the Indian Act.

I think I am justified in refusing my approval to the transfer and in asking that these children be returned to Sandy Bay Indian School.

Dear Sir:

I have been informed by the Indian Agent in Birtle that there is some dissatisfaction regarding the admittance of five Bone children from the Keeseeckocowenin Reserve.

Dealing with the case of Catherine Bone, daughter of Angus Bone; when I went to the Reserve to pick up the children Angus Bone asked if he might send this girl to school. I enquired as to his religion and he informed me he was a Presbyterian and it was vouched for by several of the Indians I knew. They stated that the child had never started to any school previously. Also the Indian Agent had no knowledge of her being in another school. In your letter you state that she is enrolled at Sandy Bay.

The other four children, two of Jonathan Bone's and two of Thomas Bone's I knew had been enrolled at Sandy Bay. Both Thomas and Jonathan were brought up Protestants as their father was always and is still a faithful attendant at the Presbyterian Church. Thomas was educated at the Birtle School and Jonathan never attended any school.

These children were not canvassed for by myself nor any member of our Church. The parents brought the children to the home of Rev. Wilson in Elphinstone expressing their desire to have them become members of the Presbyterian Church. The Rev. Wilson baptized them in this faith and they declared themselves members of this Church.

You state that a change of religion must be done in a bonafide manner. Please inform us as to what you require in this matter and it shall be looked into immediately.

Since receiving the word from the Agent I have contacted the Rev. Wilson who is sending me the declarations of the parents.

If there is any freedom of Religion for the Indian then I beg of you to reconsider this case.

Yours obediently,

N. M. Rusaw

Ottawa, December 5, 1946.

Mr. A. G. Smith, Indian Agent,
Birtle, Manitoba,

We have for answer your letter 33A of 28 November, 1946. As you are doubtless aware, the Department must be fully convinced of a bona fide change of religion before permitting children to transfer from one school to another.

Therefore, the Department wishes to obtain the following facts concerning the children about whom this controversy has arisen:

(a) In what Church was the father baptized?
(b) What school, if any, did the father attend?
(c) In what religion was the mother baptized?
(d) What school, if any, did the mother attend?
(e) By what religious denomination, if any, were they married?
(f) In what religion were the children baptized?

(Give dates - be sure to state if these children were baptized in two religions).

We have on file a letter which you forwarded from Father Lambert on 9 October, in which he states that Tobie Bone, Donald Bone, Marcellia Bone, Catherine Bone, Jean Bone, and Isabel Bone are all baptized Catholics.

...... Our records
Our records show that Ronald Bone was admitted to Sandy Bay on 21/9/43; that Frank and Murrillis Bone were admitted to Sandy Bay on 20/1/43; and that Jean and Catherine Bone were admitted on 15/9/45. As pointed out in your letter of September 23, these children apparently are from Roman Catholic families. However, the Presbyterian Church claims now that the parents are and have been Presbyterians. Can you please inform the Department of the circumstances concerning their original application forms for admission to Sandy Bay, in which these parents claimed they were Roman Catholics? Can you also obtain information as to why, at the time of the admission of these children to Sandy Bay in 1943 and 1945, we have no record of any complaint lodged by the Presbyterian Church at that time concerning their admission to this school?

The Reverend Mr. Wilson has forwarded certificates to the Department in which he states (a) that Jonathan Bone, parents and grandparents are life-long members of the Presbyterian Church in Canada, (b) that Thomas Bone is a life-long member of the Presbyterian Church in Canada and (c) that Angus Bone's parents were life-long members of the Presbyterian Church in Canada.

When we are in possession of further facts in this case, it will receive additional consideration.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Mr. Philip Phelan,
Chief of Training Division,
Indian Affairs,
Dept. of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

Would you kindly give me the Dept.'s ruling regarding age and discharge of pupils from school?

The Indian Act states that a pupil may leave at sixteen years of age. Is that to be definitely interpreted that the day a pupil becomes sixteen years old regardless of season he or she may leave school?

I have had two cases where boys became sixteen in December and their parents wanted them immediately. In both cases they petitioned the Indian Agent who gave them his consent and both went out immediately. Both gave reasons for wanting them for help. In neither case were the parents disabled or not able to work.

This leaving in the middle of the term does upset the routine of the school to a certain degree and creates uncertainty in the different school activities.

I was under the impression that when a pupil reached the age of sixteen during the term that he or she completed the term and was discharged at the end of June.

Also is a matter of mid-term discharge to be determined by the Indian Agent or put it out of the hands of the principal of the school?

Hoping that you will favour me with an early reply,

Yours obediently,

[Signature]
