Ottawa, 9 January 1947.

Rev. N.M. Rusaw, Principal,
Indian Residential School,
BIRTLE, Manitoba.

Reverend Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 6th instant, it has not been our practice to discharge pupils who reach the age of 16 during the school term.

We have always instructed Principals and others concerned that such pupils should remain in the school until the close of the academic year.

A copy of this letter is being forwarded to Indian Agent Jones.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines Resources, Ottawa.

JAN 21 1947

Re: John Ironside Age 10 years
Violet Ironside Age 13 years
Andrew Ironside Age 12 years.
Children of George Ironside, Sioux Wahpaton Res.

After the death of Mrs. Ironside these children were cared for by their Grandparents Joseph and Mrs. Omani, Sioux Wahpaton Reserve. George Ironside, the father of the children is a Protestant, he stated that his children, Violet and Andrew Ironside were placed in the Duck Lake Indian Residential School by the Grandfather in December 1940 without him, Ironside, being consulted and against his wishes.

An Application for Admission to the Duck Lake School in connection with John Ironside was received at the Office on January 13th, at the request of Ironside this Application is being held up for the present.

George Ironside is an extremely timid individual, but has a deep paternal regard and love for his children. On the other hand the Grandfather is the domineering, over-bearing type and has definitely over-ruled Ironside's wishes in every way regarding his children. For instance, Ironside requested that his children remain with him during the last summer holidays, instead, Omani took possession of the children and disappeared. Since the death of the grandmother, the children's aunt, a single woman with two illegitimate children of her own, has assisted in caring for the children.

Ironside has been living with a common-law wife until quite recently and since the fall of 1943 has been in a position to provide and care for his family. The woman Ironside has been living with left him and is, I believe, living with an
Living with an American Indian (Address unknown). However, Ironside remains firm in his demand that his children be sent to the Birtle Indian Residential School.

It has been pointed out to Ironside that the children have been Baptised by a Roman Catholic Priest, but he insists that this was against his wishes and wants his children educated in a Protestant Institution.

It is my wish that the Department make a ruling in this case.

E. F. Jones,
Indian Agent.
Ottawa, February 3rd, 1947.

E.S. Jones, Indian Agent, Leask, Sask.

We have your letter of the 16th ult., regarding the three Ironside children.

It is considered undesirable to remove these children from the Duck Lake Indian Residential School at the present time.

If necessary, you can bring the matter to our attention at the end of June and the situation will be again reviewed at that time.

Philip Phelan
Chief, Training Division.

Ottawa, May 23rd, 1947.

Dear Miss Matthews:

With reference to your letter of May 21st addressed to Mr. Hoey, we are inclined to feel that the amount mentioned as the cost of transportation of pupils from the Birtle School for the summer holidays is high.

The Principal is expected to endeavour to enlist the co-operation of the parents so that the children will be taken home and returned without cost to the Department or the school management.

Last year we allowed an amount of $180 towards the expenses of transportation of children to and from the Birtle School for summer holidays and we are prepared to allow the same amount this year.

Yours sincerely,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of May 22, file no 106-1-10(WT.7) regarding Rosemary Meccas, pupil no 0430 of this school, I beg to inform you of the facts of the case. This pupil was admitted to the Russel Hospital in the evening of Dec. 31st, 1946. She remained in the hospital until the evening of Sat. Jan. 25th. That made her in hospital a total of 25 days. In the Jan. to March Quarter there were 96 days residence. Deducting the 25 days she was away would leave sixty-five days in residence in the school in that quarter. Therefore I cannot understand where you get the 35 days overpayment in your letter.

I trust this explanation will clarify this matter.

Yours truly,

Mr. R. A. Hoey,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

Once more we are coming to you with a request for a grant towards the expenses of transportation of the children to and from the Birtle Indian School for the summer holidays. In 1946 and 1947 a grant of $180.00 was made. However, with rising costs this year we are hoping that this grant may be increased.

It seems very difficult to secure much assistance from the parents of the children towards these expenses, and the result is that our Society had had to bear an added burden.

We appreciate very much your kind co-operation in past years and would be grateful if the same consideration could be given this year.

Sincerely yours,

[Signature]
National Executive Secretary.
June 3, 1948.

Dear Miss Matthews:

Your letter of the first instant addressed to Mr. Hoey has been referred to me.

We will allow an amount not exceeding $200 towards the cost of transportation of children to and from the Birtle Residential School for holidays this summer.

The principal should prepare the account in the usual manner and submit it to the Superintendent who will forward it to the Department for payment.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

Bernard F. Neary
Superintendent of Education.

June 3, 1948.

Mr. A.G. Smith, Indian Agent,
Birtle, Manitoba.

We are advising the Women's Missionary Society of the Presbyterian Church that the Department will allow an amount not exceeding $200.00 towards the cost of transportation of children to and from the Birtle Residential School for holidays this summer.

The Secretary of the Women's Missionary Society advises us that they have great difficulty in securing any assistance from the parents of the children, towards the travelling expenses of the latter.

We feel that the parents should be urged to either take their children home or bring them back without cost either to the Department or the school management. Any assistance that you can give us in this regard would be appreciated.

Bernard F. Neary
Superintendent of Education.

September 27th, 1948.

Col. B. F. Neary,
Superintendent of Welfare and Training,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sir:

In a recent communication from Mr. Rusaw we were reminded of the promise made by your Department that we would receive an amount up to $200.00 to cover the cost of transportation of the children to and from the Birtle School for the summer vacation. I understand that Mr. Rusaw has sent in the bills to Ottawa but up to the present time we have not received a cheque to cover this amount. We should appreciate it if you would look into this matter for us.

Sincerely yours,

[Signature]
National Executive Secretary.

Constance Cook and Ivan Cook, whose father is Wilbur Cook, No. 274, Waywayssecapo Band, were admitted to the Pine Creek Indian Residential School in September, 1947. Their application forms stated that the religion of these children was Roman Catholic, and their applications were approved by the Indian Agent, who was at that time Mr. A.G. Smith.

We are now advised that these children have not returned to the Pine Creek School, but have been accepted at the Birtle Residential School. From the information that we have on file, it appears that they are not eligible for admission to the Birtle Residential School, and the Principal of that school should not have accepted them.

If they are in the Birtle School, they should be returned at once to the Pine Creek School. Please let me know when you have taken action in this matter.

Dear Sirs:

I have had correspondence from the Portage Office recently and earlier in the term over three children from the Waywayseecappo Reserve who are apparently enrolled at the Pine Creek School. Each letter has quoted a passage from your Department saying that I am to return these children to the Pine Creek School.

The children referred to are:
- Constance and Ivan Cook
- Lawrence Clowd

Please note that neither of the Cook children have been at this school at any time and where they are I do not know. I have never met nor seen either the children nor the parents. I have had telephone enquiries from the father requesting me to admit his children but he was informed that he could not as long as they were enrolled in another school without the permission of the Department.

The child, Lawrence Clowd was brought to the school here later in the fall by his parents. I knew nothing of their intentions of sending him here but he arrived when I was away for three days to Calgary. Had I been here I would not have taken him in but when I came home I could not open the door and send him out to shift for himself as he is only a small boy. I assure you that I find sufficient to do without trying to run down his parents for I do not know where they live. As for returning him to Pine Creek School I do not intend to do that either. I expect his parents may be in next week as the most of the children from that Reserve will be going home for the Christmas vacation and he can go out with them. I will then have the opportunity to contact them personally and inform them that they are not to return him to this school after the Christmas vacation. From there on is up to Pine Creek or someone else.

Your informant regarding these three children, must be of the opinion that I practice their tactics of going about each Reserve recruiting children from any home for I only go to a central meeting place at the beginning of the term and the parents meet us there.

I hope this clears up this misunderstanding.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

Dear Sir:

Pertaining to your letter dated December 9th, 1949, file No. 27-8-575, regarding payment to the CNR Railways for fares for children from Lazarre to Prince Albert, Sask., this is a long story which I have written on paper so many times now that I hope this is the last. The Railway first tried Mr. Smith, on this same thing they tried me and after they got my reply, I received a courteous letter of apology. Then they tried Mr. Davis' office in Winnipeg, who wrote me about the same thing and I explained it to him. The next move I would be is to let the person at fault make up for the error and scrap the thing.

Last June when I set out from here by truck for Lazarre arrangements had been made with the district passenger agent for accommodation on the train in the way of a separate coach. We arrived at Lazarre some time before the train time. The station was opened a few minutes before the arrival of the train by a person who was not authorized to sell tickets. This person stated that notification had been received from Winnipeg about the movement of children that night but that the agent was at a political meeting and would not be there for the train. We boarded the train on our reserved coach. The conductor endeavored to help us out. He wired to Melville (20 min. stop there) got full particulars as to numbers and ages to the ticket agent to prepare them and they would be paid for and picked up.

When we arrived at Melville I went to the ticket agent with the conductor. This agent was most disagreeable, had not done a thing about the tickets and for a minute refused to sell them. Had it not been for the conductor changing the divisional point, I do not believe he would have issued them. After a great deal of complaining he issued them at rates from Melville to Prince Albert instead of from Lazarre rates to the same place. He was definitely instructed by myself and the conductor. So you see the error was with them. After I had submitted the account to your office, they wrote about this error on their part.

You asked about the difference in amounts stated by the railway and my account. I did issue a cheque for $116.60 at Melville for the Children's fare and my own. Apparently the rate he set for mine must have been correct because they do not mention it.
The children travelled on Indian fares and I asked for regular fare one way. He must have charged me $8.45 which in comparison with their statement is certainly in order. I have paid cheque returned to the school from the bank.

Yours truly,

N. M. Rusaw.
Principal.

J. P. B. Ostrander Esq.,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies,
Regina, Sask.

Re: Pupils attending Birtle Residential School that attended Brandon last year.

We have nine boys at Birtle Residential School this year that attended Brandon Residential School last year. Mr. Strapp sent the school bus for the children from Cote Reserve on Saturday August 25, without advising me beforehand. I went around with the driver and made every effort to gather up all the children that had attended Brandon last year and we were able to muster only six girls and one boy. In all cases the parents refused to have their small boys return to this school but were quite satisfied to have the girls go back.

The parents stated that the boys were not supervised when not in the class room and that the little boys were much abused and knocked about by the older boys and if they complained to their teacher, it only resulted in more abuse from the older boys.

I discussed the matter over the telephone with Mr. Strapp the Principal of Brandon School and he advised that he did not want the boys back and he would be quite satisfied to have them transfer to another school. He promised two weeks ago to write me to this effect but has not done so.

We now have 17 pupils from Cote Reserve at Birtle school and eight of these attended Brandon school last year. I have been down to Birtle school three times in the last three weeks and the children appear to be quite happy and contented there.

I am attaching herewith the nine applications for admission to school for the children transferred from Brandon to Birtle and trust that under the circumstances the transfers will be approved by the Department.

Six of the seven girls that attended Brandon school last year are back there this year. Mary Severight had passed her 16th birthday and was discharged on the 31st August 1950.

J. L. Bryant,
Superintendent,
Indian Agency.
Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Citizenship & Immigration,
OTTAWA, Ontario.

I am enclosing applications for admission to residential school, and Mr. Bryant's covering letter, which is self-explanatory.

I would recommend that Mr. Bryant's proposal be accepted and he be notified to make the transfers.

J.P.B. Ostrander,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies,
Saskatchewan.

Dear Sir:

I, today, am in receipt of a letter from Mr. J. Rayson, Supt., of the Indian Agency at Portage La Prairie, Man., stating that authority had been received for the admission of Clara & Ruth Oudie on Dec.1/50 to this school. He also advised that the Department disapproved our taking children and increasing the enrolment here.

I thought I explained the reason for taking these two girls in as we really did not wish to have them. Clara was about to be discharged from the Brandon San. from a three year illness and treatment. Bone from this girl's leg was transplanted in the base of her spine. Dr. Tyre, the Supt., at the San., did not wish to see this girl return to her home on the Reserve as he feared her condition might return and if so it would be fatal. He wanted her where she could get plenty of rest and good food. I felt it was the Christian thing to do and took her in. When she came the parents sent the younger one who had cried to come with Clara to School and sent the girls here with another person. They were here and I could not just send them away.

I have been doing all within my power to have the Indians put in the applications earlier for admissions and have been discouraging the practice of bringing children in after Sept., unless there is a logical reason. I have turned away six different children who have been brought in since Oct.1st. and have equally as many phone calls seeking admission. So please do not think that I am canvassing for these children or using influential measures to increase the enrolment. This school is spacious and will accommodate 150 to 160 easier than several schools I know who have a much higher quota than this school has.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

Mr. J. Rayson, Superintendent of the Indian Agency at Portage La Prairie, Man., has referred your enquiry to me re Nelson Tanner, a student at this school. The reference letter is dated Nov. 5th, 51 and file no is 575-10(E6).

Your enquiry pertaining to this lad or any student taking High School work here was a great surprise to me. This lad is twenty years of age but as a younger pupil did not start school until ten years of age. He also spent a year in his childhood in the Sanatorium. At the present he is completing his grade twelve. It is true he has failed once in two subjects but it is his own will and wish to complete his High School. He works faithfully and is most anxious to be a success. His family background is just about the worst and the Indians from his Reserve are doing all they can to discourage any of their band to be desirous of education. In spite of this, Nelson has plodded ahead and I feel sure he will make use of his training. He is developing into a very fine young man and people who have met him from the Department are quite pleased with his manner and action. When Major McKay was here he met this lad personally and the majority of these older students. If you would approach him on this matter I am sure he will be able to explain it much better than I.

May I mention here that the Birtle School is not overcrowded to the extent of crowding. Large spaces formerly used for storage and workshop etc., have been changed to sleeping rooms etc., for students. An outside workshop and store house has been moved from the old agency property and much space has been made available for housing etc.

Yours very truly,

When you are brightening up your house for spring, don't forget the bedroom. A bed spread made of figured materials such as English linen, percale, or cotton and silk fabrics makes a room more cheerful and attractive.

Two widths of most materials stitched together are enough for a spread. The wide valance which hangs within four or five inches of the floor may be neatly gathered on the two sides and across the bottom of the spread. Bands of harmonizing color may be used for trimming.

A straight piece of figured material or plain material that harmonizes with the spread and with other colors, will serve as a pillow cover. Colored spreads may be used to add to the color scheme of the room and to break up the monotony often caused by a large expanse of white bed spread.

English Influence Called the Basis of Indian Advance

Professor Says Renaissance Has Become Great Moral Force in India

Bombay.—The first gift of the English of India was universal peace or freedom from foreign influence, obtained Prof. Jodh Sarkar, who is the Vice-Chancellor of Calcutta University, in a lecture he gave recently.

The speaker added: "The English have brought peace to the entire outside world; not only in Asia, but in all other continents as well; and they have admitted the rest of the world to us in a degree not dreamed of under Muslim rule. English has been switched on to the main currents of the great moving world outside and made to vibrate with every economic or cultural change there. An isolated life is no longer possible even for our remote villages.

"It is, therefore," continued Prof. Sarkar, "of peculiar advantage to us that in this age of world-forces our official language is English, and that it has diffused itself all over India as the medium of trading and political and cultural correspondence. No other European language has the worldwide influence of English, or is used by such a large proportion of the human race. And English literature is the richest in the world on account of its own original works as well as the translations from all other languages in almost every branch of thought."

The greatest gift of the English besides universal peace and the modernization of India is the Renaissance, the direct result of these two forces—a renaissance which marked our nineteenth century. Modern India owes everything to it; literature, education, thought, art, but in the last generation it became a moral force and reformed our society and religion; still later, in the third generation from its commencement, it has led to the beginning of the economic modernization of India," concluded the Vice-Chancellor.

Further to your letter 106-1-4 of May 9th and our reply of May 14th, I wish to report as follows on the Indian Residential School, Birtle, which I inspected June 7th, 1940.

The roll calls for 111 pupils. Miss Todd has the junior room with 48 enrolled, 40 in Grade 1 and 8 in Grade 2. The senior room is in charge of Mr. Ingelson with 63 enrolled and the grades arranged as follows -

Both teachers are qualified and appear to be doing good work. Unfortunately, both are resigning June 30th.

The children are fairly well dressed. They are neat in appearance and clean. They all appeared interested in their studies and discipline was good. The work books were neat and the handwriting good. I believe the children, in both classrooms, are making progress.

All dormitories were clean and well aired. The beds were neatly made and the bedding appeared ample and clean. A few beds were in poor condition, but I understand these are being replaced. A number are without castors, which fact I pointed out to Mr. Lockhart, the principal. Beds without castors gradually dig into the cement floors and will, in time, cause considerable damage. I consider repairs of this nature should be attended to by the principal.

The playroom and washroom on the girls' side was clean and all plumbing in good condition. The playroom walls are plastered with grey cement. I suggested these walls be whitewashed with lime or some suitable preparation. This would tend to destroy any germs and would greatly brighten the rooms. On the boys' side these rooms were also clean but the playroom walls needed some repair. These walls should also be cleaned, either by lime or by some similar preparation.

The dining room was clean and the tables neatly arranged. Some tables are in need of repair and bracing. I pointed this out to Mr. Lockhart and there is no reason why this work can not be done by a staff member, assisted by the boys.

Dr. H. W. McGill,
Director of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA.
The kitchen is in the charge of Mrs. Cruikshanks, who also supervises the bakery and dairy. I consider these departments well operated. One girl was busy making apple pies, and she appeared quite accustomed to the work. Bread is baked for the entire school. The children appeared in excellent health and apparently receive plenty of good food.

The boiler room is in charge of Mr. Dunn, who has been engineer here for some years. The equipment appears in good condition. Some repair is needed on the outlet provided for taking the ashes from the furnace room. The cordwood has been thrown in at this opening, which is in front of the furnace, instead of dropping it into the fuel room proper. To repair this outlet will require six or eight bags of cement and considerable labour. The repair work should be done this summer and in the future, this outlet should only be used for taking out the ashes. The hoist for lifting the ashes is located in this opening, and sooner or later it will be destroyed if they continue to throw the cordwood in against it. The wood should be put in through the fuel room.

The barns and outbuildings are in good repair but badly in need of painting. Mr. Lockhart stated he had a considerable amount of money to the credit of his school in Toronto. If such is the case, I think some should be used to paint the two main barns. Mr. Lockhart has had no big crops so apparently this accumulation is from the school grants. Other principals do repair work and I see no reason why Mr. Lockhart can not do some too.

He has thirty-five head of cows and young stock. At present there are eleven milking, with about eight to freshen. There are sixteen stalls for milking cows and the principal aims to keep these full. He has disposed of all surplus bulls. The cattle are in excellent condition.

Dear Sir,

Further to your letter 106-1-4 of May 9th and our reply of May 14th, I wish to report as follows on the Indian Residential School, Birtle, which I inspected June 7th, 1940.

The roll calls for 111 pupils. Miss Todd has the junior room with 48 enrolled, 40 in Grade 1 and 8 in Grade 2. The senior room is in charge of Mr. Ingelson with 63 enrolled and the grades arranged as follows -

| Grade | Number |
|-------|--------|
| 3     | 27     |
| 4     | 23     |
| 5     | 8      |
| 6     | 4      |
| 8     | 1      |

Both teachers are qualified and appear to be doing good work. Unfortunately, both are resigning June 30th.

The children are fairly well dressed. They are neat in appearance and clean. They all appeared interested in their studies and discipline was good. The work books were neat and the handwriting good. I believe the children, in both classrooms, are making progress.

All dormitories were clean and well aired. The beds were neatly made and the bedding appeared ample and clean. A few beds were in poor condition but I understand these are being replaced. A number are without castors, which fact I pointed out to Mr. Lockhart the principal. Beds without castors gradually dig into the cement floors and will, in time, cause considerable damage. I consider repairs of this nature should be attended to by the principal.

The playroom and washroom on the girls' side was clean and all plumbing in good condition. The playroom walls are plastered with grey cement. I suggested these walls be whitewashed with lime or some suitable preparation. This would tend to destroy any germs and would greatly brighten the rooms. On the boys' side these rooms were also clean but the playroom walls needed some repair. These walls should also be cleaned, either by lime or by some similar preparation.

The dining room was clean and the tables neatly arranged. Some tables are in need of repair and bracing. I pointed this out to Mr. Lockhart and there is no reason why this work can not be done by a staff member, assisted by the boys.

Dr. H. W. McGill,
Director of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA.
The kitchen is in the charge of Mrs. Cruikshanks, who also supervises the bakery and dairy. I consider these departments well operated. One girl was busy making apple pies, and she appeared quite accustomed to the work. Bread is baked for the entire school. The children appeared in excellent health and apparently receive plenty of good food.

The boiler room is in charge of Mr. Dunn, who has been engineer here for some years. The equipment appears in good condition. Some repair is needed on the outlet provided for taking the ashes from the furnace room. The cordwood has been thrown in at this opening which is in front of the furnace, instead of dropping it into the fuel room proper. To repair this outlet will require six or eight bags of cement and considerable labour. The repair work should be done this summer and in the future, this outlet should only be used for taking out the ashes. The hoist for lifting the ashes is located in this opening, and sooner or later it will be destroyed if they continue to throw the cordwood in against it. The wood should be put in through the fuel room.

The barns and outbuildings are in good repair but badly in need of painting. Mr. Lockhart stated he had a considerable amount of money to the credit of his school in Toronto. If such is the case, I think some should be used to paint the two main barns. Mr. Lockhart has had no big crops so apparently this accumulation is from the school grant. Other principals do repair work and I see no reason why Mr. Lockhart can not do some too.

He has thirty five head of cows and young stock. At present there are eleven milking, with about eight to freshen. There are sixteen stalls for milking cows and the principal aims to keep these full. He has disposed of all surplus bulls. The cattle are in excellent condition.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

Mr. Lockhart of the Birtle School has written that he needs a new tractor. He has a chance of buying a second hand one for $720.00 which he says is worth $950.00. It cost $1500.00 two and a half years ago. It is a McCormack Deering W30.

Memorandum of an inquiry into the cause and circumstances of the death of
Karl Pratt, Pupil No. 306,
of the Birtle Indian Residential School at Birtle, Manitoba,
who died at Birtle, Manitoba (place) on 1st November 1947.

INSTRUCTIONS

When a pupil of an Indian Residential School dies, the Principal is required to inform the Indian Agent at once.

On receipt of the Principal's notice the Indian Agent shall convene a Board of Inquiry, consisting of himself as Chairman, the Principal of the Residential School, and the Medical Officer who attended the deceased pupil. These members of the Board shall, in each other's presence, complete this memorandum, which shall then be forwarded to the Department of Indian Affairs, Ottawa, in one copy.

The Board of Inquiry shall, if at all practicable assemble within 48 hours of the pupil's death.

The parents or guardians of the deceased pupil shall be given notice of this inquiry and be permitted to attend it or to send a representative. They or their representative shall be asked if they wish to make a statement. In the event of their so wishing, their statement shall be attached to the report. The inquiry, however, shall not be delayed more than 72 hours after the time at which it would otherwise be held, to enable them to attend it.

If the Indian Agent is located at such a distance from the school as to make it impracticable for him to attend the Board, he shall request a responsible local resident to act for him. A suitable person for this duty would be a Justice of the Peace or a member of the Royal Canadian Mounted or Provincial Police. A more or less permanent arrangement of this kind might be necessary in some cases. The Department is prepared to pay a reasonable fee for this duty, on the Agent's recommendation. The report of the Board, in any case, must reach the Department through the Indian Agent's office.

This inquiry is not designed to take the place of, or prevent, any other inquiry, including an inquest, which may be required by law.

If the pupil died as the result of an accident, the Indian Agent is required to take the statements of the witnesses of the accident, and attach them to this memorandum.

Dear Sir:

I am enclosing herewith the Memorandum of an inquiry into the cause of the death of Earl Pratt, a pupil at the Birtle Residential School, who died yesterday.

This boy was very ill by 3 p.m. yesterday afternoon and died about 7 p.m. Owing to the absence of the Principal during the afternoon, the boy's relatives on the Bird Tail Sioux Reserve were not notified of his condition, or of his death, until I did so about 12 p.m., although they live only fourteen miles from the school, on a fair road.

The Principal did not return home until shortly before the boy's death, and I was absent on the way back to the Reserve until 10 p.m., when I was notified of the death of this boy.

Sir,

I am led to the conclusion that there are enough of Indian children, (as will be seen from reference to the enclosed list), to justify the establishment of an Industrial School for the Indians of the proposed district. It would appear however, that one great difficulty with regard to the location of such an institution in

Dr. Sutherland for an Industrial School to be established, in the interest of the Indian children whose parents are Methodists, somewhere near the lower end of Lake Winnipeg. The Indian Commissioner states that the number of children of school age under the

the Methodist body in that region would appear to warrant the establishment of such an institution; but that from enquiries made he does not consider that a suitable location could be secured in Lake Winnipeg owing to the want of adaptability of the soil for agriculture, and the consequent impossibility of establishing a farm of any considerable size in connection with the institution; but that he would recommend that the School be located in the neighborhood of Selkirk, with a view to obtaining employment for the pupils in industrial pursuits from the settlers, and that thus by their mingling with white people they would be more likely to assimilate themselves with the ways of the white population and be prevented from developing into

In the event however of the Department not concurring in his views on the above point, the Indian Commissioner recommends that the best place, if the school is to be established in the neighborhood of the Reserve, would be about the mouth of the Saskatchewan, where the land is least unfavorable for agriculture.

Ottawa, 30th January, 1889

Dear Mr. Dewdney:

In reply to the enquiry made by you on my report respecting the location for the Methodist Industrial School in the Manitoba Superintendency, as to whether land is available at Selkirk, I beg to remind you that there is a quantity of land which forms part of the townplot of Selkirk and which originally was included in the St. Peter's Reserve but was surrendered some time ago by these Indians to be sold for their benefit. As far as the site for the school is concerned I think that we could probably find a suitable one in this tract, but for farming purposes it would not be possible to appropriate sufficient land thereon. We should have in that case to endeavor to effect some such arrangement as was made for the Church of England Industrial School, viz., to exchange with some party public lands for a desirable site, if sufficient of the former of a suitable character cannot be obtained near Selkirk.

In this connection I should have stated that Dr. Sutherland had suggested that the School be established at Fisher River Reserve. So far as land is concerned I think we could probably obtain a fair proportion of cultivable land in that locality, but the other advantages mentioned in Mr. Reed's letter, which would accrue to the pupils through intercourse with White people and obtaining employment at their trades, could not be
secured to them at Fisher River, which is purely an Indian settlement; and, so far as I can see at present, the latter consideration should have the preponderance in deciding the question of the location of the School.

Yours sincerely

(sgd) L. Vankoughnet

My Dear Reed,

With reference to your letter of the 14th instant, I today wired you in effect that I saw no objection to expending up to $6,000., the sum voted for a Methodist School, Manitoba, on the Morley Institution; but before making any payments you should ascertain from personal knowledge what additions were required, and forward plan and specifications, with an estimate of the cost, to the Department. The money, as you are aware, will lapse on the 30th June. Of course the books are kept open until towards the end of September, in order to allow vouchers for expenditure to reach the Department, but no expenditure dated later than the 30th of June can be charged.
charged against the appropriation for that year. In order to overcome the difficulty that presents itself in this case, (there not being time to complete the work before the 30th of June), it is suggested that if the church will agree, and give a guarantee to build the addition itself, according to the plan and specifications approved by the Department, the amount intended to be given it might be paid over to a Board appointed for the purpose, as indicated by the vote, which reads,—

"For a Grant of $6,000 toward a Methodist Industrial School in Manitoba". An Order-in-Council would have to be obtained before the transfer of the money could be carried out. If this arrangement can be effected it will matter little whether the work be completed before the 30th of June or not; however, it will be considered when the particulars are received from you.

In regard to the St. Boniface School, as you know, we
we have only $6,000 to spend, and it is in exactly the same position as the money voted for the Methodist School. I telegraphed you today to know where the plans and specifications were. On receipt of these, with an estimate, we may undertake to make the same arrangement in regard to paying the Grant on that suggested for the Wesley improvements, but it must be distinctly understood that no more than the sum voted can be expended. The Department has no power to spend more than is authorized by Parliament to expend, and I shall take no responsibility in the way of authorising the erection of buildings that are to cost more than we have money to pay for, such as was done in the case of the St. Paul's School. In regard to the land for a site for the proposed school, I understand that the Church people will agree to exchange the 34 acres at St. Boniface for equal value in lands elsewhere in the Province.

OTTAWA 10th April, 1894

Rev. Sir,

As you are doubtless aware the Department after having had a somewhat varied and extended experience of the plan of maintaining Industrial Schools by providing for all their requirements as such might arise, became impressed by the idea that greater efficiency combined with economy and satisfaction to all concerned in carrying on the work would result from its abandonment in favor of a system of maintenance by per capita grant. This change having been introduced has been found to work so satisfactorily as to induce the conclusion that it would be well to bring the proposed school at Brandon under it from the start, for the Department feels convinced that economy in management will be much more easily and effectually learned from the beginning, and the difficulty and unsatisfactoriness of afterwards cutting down what cannot properly be allowed to continue avoided.

The following are the conditions upon which it is proposed that the Church shall assume the maintenance of the school:

- The school to be built and once completed equipped by the Government.
- Subsequent purchases of outfit to be defrayed by the management.

In case, however, of the number of pupils authorized being increased beds will be provided.

Rev. J. McDougall,
Ottawa

Returns of attendance, admissions, discharges &c., such as required from similar institutions by the Department shall be made.

The whole institution, including accounts records &c. will be open to inspection at any time to the Department, and the management will render all necessary assistance to facilitate the making of such inspections.

NEW INDIAN SCHOOLS.

Rev. John Semmens on His Way to Being Pupils to Brandon Institute.

Rev. John Semmens, principal of the New Indian Schools recently at Brandon, arrived in the city yesterday on his way to Norway house and likely will pass on Lake Winnipeg to bring down the supplies now coming from the several missions to the north. He is expected to leave on Thursday morning for West Selkirk, where he will take passage by the Northwest Navigation Company's steamer, Red River. He will probably arrive in Norway House about the 1st of July.

Rev. Semmens is very pleased with the farm and buildings provided for the institution. The school farm, he says, embraces half a section of land, immediately west of the Experimental Farm grounds northwest of Brandon. A large part of the land is under cultivation. The property is beautifully situated on the south side of the Souris River. A fine view is afforded from the Institution to the City of Brandon also of Chuter, the City of Selkirk, Norway House, ten miles west, and the country between.

The building is of brick on stone foundation, two stories high, 50 feet above the basement. It is in the form of an "H," the main portion 30 feet in height and 30 feet in width. The front to the end of the wing is also 30 feet in height and 30 feet in proportion. The Smead-David system of heating and ventilating the entire building is used. Furnaces placed in the basement supply heat for the baths and kitchen, and also supply heated air for the whole building. Entering the building, the visitor finds the office to the left, and the reception room to the right. Proceeding, the class rooms are reached, one on each side of the hall, which is lighted by eight windows. In the rear are the dining-room and kitchens. Ascending one flight of stairs, another room is reached; it is furnished with machines for sewing, knitting, weaving, tailoring. In the same manner are arranged the rooms for members of the staff. Advancing toward the rear, the house comes to the dormitories, to the right those for the girls, to the left those for the boys, and to the left those for the girls. On either side are wash rooms and bath rooms for the convenience of the pupils. Passing to the third story, here are the rooms which are supplied from a well on the premises by means of a force pump, which is operated by steam. There are several rooms for members of the staff, also rooms for use in case of winter and rainy days. To the rear are the storeroom, nurses' room and sick room for boys and girls. The rooms for members of the staff are all comfortably furnished. The dormitories are supplied with beds, blankets, pillows, robes.

The following appointments to the staff of the institute have been made: Rev. John Semmens, principal; Mr. Spence, of Brandon, teacher; Mr. H. Todd, farm instructor; Mr. Jarvis, assistant; Misses Smith and Misses Peters; Henry Quackenbush, carpenter. Several other instructors are yet to be appointed; their names have not yet been submitted.

Dear Sir:

I submit herewith a brief account of the journey recently undertaken under the direction of the Department for the purpose of bringing Indian children to the Brandon School.

Left Brandon, June 12th took the boat at West Selkirk on the evening of the 13th. Made a good run first night, reaching Bull's Head shortly after breakfast of the second day. Stayed until evening wooding up, proceeded northward during the night and anchored off Berens River early in the morning of the third day arriving at the latter place about dusk, after lying at anchor all day.

June 16th-17th, Discharging cargo, and spending the Sabbath day in rest at Berens River.

June 18th, Steamed out of Berens River harbor at night fall, anchored at Swampy Island 12 miles from point of starting at 10 P.M.

June 19th, Left Swampy Island after breakfast, Made Georgey's Island about 50 miles, anchored early in the afternoon. Left Georgey's late at night arriving at Warren's.
Warren's Landing at 4 O'clock on the 20th.

21st. All day hard aground.

22nd. Started a boat to Norway House for assistance. Put off some cargo, moved a little way and grounded again.

23rd. Put off some more cargo and go on the way reaching Norway House about noon.

24th--25th. Discharging cargo at Norway House

26th. Got the children on board steamer and proceeded a few miles south, and anchored for the night.

27th. Started early broke the wheel in the first hour, cast anchor 22 miles from Norway House and sent for assistance.

28th. Loaded stones on the steamer all the day to lift the wheel out of the water. Piled cordwood in the bow, Boys helped well. Wheel put on late at night.

29th. Started early, ran four miles and went hard on a rock Compelled to send back to Norway House for assistance.

30th. Worked hard all day trying to free the steamer from the rock.

1st July (Monday morning) Steamer left the rocks at 9 A.M. proceeded up stream about four miles and anchored through stress of weather.

3rd July. Weather still stormy, Did not move until 9 P.M. when we got free and moved southward to Georgey's Island.

4th July. Ran against heavy winds all day, reached Swampy Island by dark. Continued to Bull's Head during the night.

Reached
Reached Selkirk early in the morning of the 5th, were taken across to East Selkirk, and reached Brandon sometime after midnight.

6th July. Moved the children from the cars into the Industrial School.

It might be observed that we should have reached the end of our journey on the 30th, had we made good time from Norway House. Detention will naturally increase the expense of the trip unless the Company should charge for what might have been a straight course between Norway House and Selkirk.

I found a very determined compact against Brandon among the Treaty Indians, who seemed resolved not to send their children to this place. Owing to the distance from Lake Winnipeg, and the impossibility of the parents ever seeing their children during their stay at the school, this was the one general reason for their opposition to this site. At Norway House, in addition to the foregoing there was also manifested a very great unwillingness to have the children used for any purpose other than in the school. They had entertained the thought that it was the purpose of the Department to make money out of their children and to this they had determined not to submit.

It was a pleasant feature of our journey that with the exception of a slight cold no child has had any sickness since the day of our leaving Norway House.

PREPARATIONS FOR THE OPENING OF THE BRANDON INDIAN INDUSTRIAL SCHOOL

Rev. John Semmens, chairman of the Lake Winnipeg District, was absent from the session of Conference at Regina, having been instructed by the Bishop of Rupert's Land to go to Brandon and take charge, at Norway House and other points on Lake Winnipeg, of the Indian children who are to attend the Boarding School in that place. He expects to return about July 1 with about forty pupils, possibly more. He left for the north on the day following the close of the autumnal session of the Conference, Thursday, June 13, by the Southwest Navigation Company's steamer, Root River.

Mr. Semmens is very much pleased with the farm which has been provided for the purpose of the Institute. The farm, he says, embraces half a section of land immediately west of the Experimental Farm grounds, on the Assiniboine, west of Brandon. A large part of the land is under cultivation. The property is beautifully situated on the north side of the Assiniboine River. A fine view is afforded from the institute grounds overlooking the river, Chats, ten miles east, and of Kemnay, ten miles west, and the country between.

The building is of brick on stone foundation, three stories in height, above the basement. It is in the form of a T. The front is 82 feet in length and 30 feet in width. The wing from front to end of the wing is also 92 feet; and the width of this portion 30 feet. The open Doric system of heating ventilation and closets is used. Furnaces placed in the basement heat the water for the baths, kitchens, etc., and supply heated air for the whole building. On the first floor are the office, reception room, two class rooms, library, dining-room, schoolroom, kitchens; on the second, the seamstresses' room, private rooms for members of the staff and dormitories for the pupils; fifth floor, private rooms and bath-rooms supplied with every convenience. The third story contains six tanks which are supplied from the spring, the kitchen, recreation rooms, store room, nurse's room and sick rooms.

As the training of Indians in industrial institutions is opened the question arises, how can these young people, on the completion of their training, be enabled to earn their living in the "white race"? They will not be able to return to their former homes and pursue the industries, blacksmithing, carpentry, tailoring, shoemaking, etc., of which they will have acquired. If they scatter through the white settlements and try to earn their living there, they will starve. Their existence for the benefit of other Indians will, to a great extent, depend upon their ability to earn what the great majority of the people, those who cannot be trained in industrial institutes, to make them self-supporting. The Indians are now living in sections of the country unsuitable for agriculture. Their present means of subsistence hunting, fishing, gathering berries, etc., are year to year more precarious. To remove the whole population to agricultural districts and supply them with draft animals, stock, implements, etc., the training requisite to make them farmers, would be beyond the resources of the government if practicable. An experiment begun a few years ago in Alaska and now stated to be resulting successfully concerns the raising of reindeer here. Sixteen reindeer were imported at an expense of a couple of thousand dollars, and some Laplanders were sent out to teach the Indians how to raise, train and use them. The Laplanders, it is said, will return to their own country when the Indians have learned the business, but by that time the Alaskans will understand the reindeer business and will be able to live independently. When in Winnipeg the other day, Rev. John Semmens was asked how he thought such a plan would work in the Indians south of Lake Winnipeg. The plan was not new to him; Sir John Schultz, the Lieutenant-Governor of Manitoba, had visited the reindeer station upon the subject, warmly advocating the enterprise. Mr. Semmens pointed out that nature has already provided the facilities for the development of such an industry; as there are thousands of reindeer running wild in the north country, proving its adaptation to the feeding of these animals.

I don't feel like staying here for a long time, because the boys are not very good, and they are quarrelling among themselves nearly every day. They are not allowed to use bad language, but they frequently use bad words and call each other by nasty names.

Sometimes they persuade me to do something that is not good or right, so I don't want to associate with these ignorant and self-willed Indian children.

I struck one boy last night because he was teasing me down in the closets and tried to lock me in. When I got out I hit him and he always calls me names. I told Mr Simmons about it, but he did not make him stop and I am afraid they will make me wild and quarrelsome soon.

I would like to stay here only till next June, because I don't want to quarrel with these boys all the time. I would rather go back to the reserve to work on the farm than teach school, because my friends want me to work with them, especially in hay making time, but I want to do whatever you tell me to do, because you know better than I know.

If Mr. Simmons can't make these boys stop quarrellings, you may be able to do something to them.

That boy whom I hit wants to stab me with a Jack Knife at the prayer time, but I am not afraid of him.

The teachers and carpenter are not very kind to me or help me in my studies, and when I ask them anything, they said: all right; will see, and they did not do it.
I would be pleased, if you would answer this letter and I would be greatly obliged.

I am Sir.

Yours Obediently,

My Dear Sir:-

I received your welcome letter yesterday, and was glad to hear from you.

The boys are not so bad as two weeks ago, during the Principal's absence, and I will never quarrel with any of the boys again as long as I stay here; as we are told that we will do good to those who do harm to us, and help them they that are weak.

I am always trying to be obedient to those who rule over us, and listen to the laws. But however there are some great obstacles in the way of doing what is right in our daily life, and contaminating to the influence of sins, and try to give up the work which we now occupy.

Should you be met however with the repetition of the offence by the same boy, you would I think be justified in using less leniency, such as depriving the boy of a holiday, or some other privilege, or by a simple diet for a day or two, or as a last resort, unless the boy had great provocation, by corporal punishment.

Dear Sir,

As stated in my telegram of the 17th inst., three boys were arrested on the evening of that day and sent to the police court. On Saturday they were tried before a Police Magistrate, and in view of apparent carelessness (indifference?) were sent to the Gaol for a week. After the sentence came the telegram from your office directing me to delay the proceedings until matters should have been talked over with Inspector Wadsworth. I have been to the Depot two nights in succession but have failed to identify him. Your letter of this morning explains the reason of the delay.

Now as to the circumstances of the case, I was in town at the time and a few minutes before the occurrence telephoned Mr Todd and satisfied myself that all was well. It appears that Mr T found one of the boys misbehaving a little later and told him to desist. This he flatly refused to do, the Officer persisted, there was continued refusal.
refusal whereupon Mr Todd laid his hand upon him and compelled obedience. As soon as this was observed the other boys near came to the pupils aid and all three joined in the assault only one person actually striking blows but others holding Mr Todd. It is verily believed that but for the timely arrival of Mr Quackenbush Mr Todd would have been roughly handled.

Mr Todd immediately drove into town swore out a warrant and asked for police interference.

My own consent was given on the following grounds:

1) This had occurred three times before and the officers were annoyed at my laxity in only demanding apologies. It was of course time to protect ourselves (2) The boys had been repeatedly warned that this arrest might follow a repetition of this offence. (3) The offence was as far as I could gather without sufficient cause. (4) It was time that some deterrent influence were brought to bear upon others who threatened vengeance upon Mr Todd and who were quite inclined to be ugly and defiant.

Next morning the Magistrate determined to dispose of the case but the boys were laughing and apparently enjoying the farce, I had asked that they be incarcerated but for the night but they were so defiant still that the Magistrate thought it better to leave them to their thoughts for a week. I shall await the coming of Inspector Wadsworth and if he thinks best we can jointly request their release.

I have, etc.

sgd John Semmens.

Sir,

Referring to Departmental letter of February 17th, No. 64411, and my answer thereto of March 4th, stating that the letter would be laid before the Executive Committee of the Board of Missions, and a definite reply sent thereon, I beg now to say that the memorandum of the terms upon which the Brandon Industrial school is to be assumed by the Missionary Society on a per capita basis, seems to be fair and reasonable, and they are agreed to accordingly, with the understanding that any unforeseen circumstance or emergency not covered by these terms, would be considered by the Department on its merits, and such action taken as the case would fairly call for.

I observe that nothing is said in the memorandum as to the expense of bringing new pupils to the Institute, or sending them home when their term expires, or when their removal may be ordered by the Indian Commissioner. This is a kind of expenditure which I think should be provided for by the Department outside of the per capita grant.

In order that the carrying on of the Institute on a per capita basis may be assumed by us under satisfactory conditions, it is important that steps be taken at once to increase the number of pupils to at least 80; the remaining 20 authorized by the Department to be dealt with subsequently from time to time as opportunity may afford. I would respectfully suggest therefore that the Principal of the Institute be authorized by the Department to proceed by the earliest steamer up Lake Winnipeg with a view to securing additional pupils for the Institute.

In this connection I would refer also to a suggestion made some
time ago by the Principal, namely that two or three of the older boys be taken to visit the Reserves from which they came as the most effective way of removing any unfavorable impression from the minds of the Indians caused by misleading reports that have been circulated among them.

There is another point to which I would call attention that we deem of great importance, and that is, that all employees in the Institute who have been appointed by the Department should at once be notified that their engagement will terminate with the 30th day of June. This does not mean that there will be an entire change of staff, nor indeed that any change will be made without good and sufficient reasons, but simply that the employees may understand that from the time that the Institute is assumed by the Missionary Society on the per capita basis, all appointments or dismissals rest with the Principal and the authorities of the Missionary Society. Without this, as we view it, it will be impossible to maintain either discipline or efficiency on the part of the employees. At the same time no employee will be retained who, in the judgment of the Department, is inefficient or unsuited to the position.

I am,

Sir,

Your obedient servant

In reference to the letter herewith from the Rev Dr. Sutherland on the subject of the transfer of the Brandon Industrial school to the Methodist Missionary Society on the per capita system, the undersigned begs to state that the Executive Committee of the Board of Missions say they are satisfied with the Memorandum of the terms upon which the school is to be assumed by them; but Dr Sutherland calls the attention of the Department to the omission in the Memorandum of any mention as to the expense of bringing in new pupils to the Institute, or sending them home when their time expires, and he states that he is of opinion that such expenditure should be provided for by the Department outside the per capita grant.

There is no appropriation specially made for the purpose of bringing in new pupils or returning those whose time has expired, although the Department has, from time to time, paid the expenses of pupils to Industrial schools in the first instance, and notably in the case of Brandon school when it paid $600 for this service. It was then thought that pupils might be had nearer the school at less expense. The Methodist Missionary Society are however, apparently anxious to bring pupils in from the upper end of Lake Winnipeg where they have a number of mission stations.

The return for March quarter from the Brandon school shows that there were 69 pupils enrolled, leaving II vacancies to be filled to bring the school up to its quota of 80 pupils, and if the Department sanctions the trip up Lake Winnipeg to obtain these pupils it should only be on the understanding that it was not to be called upon to go to any more expense in this direction.
as the school once being filled up it is more in the interest of the Society than of the Department to keep up the attendance.

The suggestion to take two or three of the older boys for the purpose of reconciling the Indians to parting with their children and removing any unfavourable impression from their minds caused from misleading reports being circulated among them, is a good one and would it is thought have the desired effect, and was previously agreed to if another trip of the above nature was authorized.

A good deal of friction is said to exist between the Principal and his staff and the attention of the Department has on several occasions been called to the lack of harmony existing among the employees, but owing to the contemplated handing over of the school to the Church authorities in the near future, it was decided not to make any changes and the Church authorities were informed that when this school was placed in their hands they would be at liberty to re-organize the staff to suit themselves.

It has always been recognized by the Department that when a school is placed on the per capita basis those assuming its control are responsible for its management and maintenance.

THE BRANDON INDIAN INSTITUTE

Impressions Gathered From Visitors of the General Board of Missions.

One of the leading topics of conversation among members of the Methodist general board of missions during the meeting at Brandon, outside of the immediate business of the board, was the Industrial Institute of the Canadian Industrial Institute. With splendid roads and fine weather, the drive is a most enjoyable one. The scenery, obtained from different points of view along the hills, is very pleasing in the fall when the leaves appear in varied tints; as well as in summer when the rich foliage covers the avenue in places with a green canopy. The institute has been visited by others through the experience of going there. The bird's-eye view of that institution, both from the air and from the ground, how to supplement with facts and experiences, is something which cannot be done under Mr. Bedford's superintendence.

Visitors to the Industrial Institute are favorably impressed with the sight of the school buildings, which are located and admirably kept. After seeing how much energy, time, money, and skill are employed, together with the talents and enthusiasm of the instructors, who are doing the best interests of the pupils, some wonder why the Indians would not be better off such training. It may be said that the Indian boys and girls in such a school would be better off than white children. They are given the things which the white children need, but which is not provided for them. It is said that double the amount of work is done by Canadians as to the success of the industrial institute, and the solution of the Indian problem. It is possible that the industrial institute gives a measure of education. An Indian boy is not helped forward by being taught how to make a gun instead of an expert use of a gun; or by being taught how to make a writer rather than to make moccasins. If the forests of the remote north are to be opened up, the knowledge how to catch fish is more valuable than the knowledge how to make a shoe in a country where there never have been any shoes made before. To learn farming will be largely a lost of time if one is to live in a country where there are no cultivators.

The Reverend Ferrier is turning his attention to the problem of finding for his boys a good trade. He is using the knowledge and skill which they acquire. At the time of the visit, several of the boys who were away earning handsome wages in the harvest fields, gave good satisfaction to their employers. His girls, too, have no difficulty in finding good situations as domestics.

One incomprehensible feature of the Industrial Institute is the fact that one which nobody undertook to do, is the rigid exclusion of all white children from the advantages of the industrial training. That there are hundreds of white children who ought to be dealt with in the same manner is a fact. There are girls in Winnipeg who could earn a living, and there are boys here and elsewhere, of every nationality, who could grow up to be useful men if they had been given the opportunity. Indian children would be most efficiently taught English if they were brought up and played with English-speaking children. The teachers are opposed to the idea of exceptions of enforcing the speaking of English by children who are to be forbidden, almost with harshness, to speak their own language. The teachers feel greatly relieved, when they can get children from India, so that they may be obliged to use English, and not be obliged to be unable to understand each other's languages. They are convinced of the absurdity of the arrangement, if it were not for the fact that the children are of Dookhobor children, or those of any other nationality. No one can imagine anything more unreasonable for any class of foreigners an educational institution. The children are away from their homes, where the children are educated in their own language with English-speaking children, and yet they are forced to speak only English. A teacher of English in a Dookhobor schoolhouse said he did not find it difficult to get the children to speak English, whereas a teacher of English among English-speaking children answered: "Yes, I find it difficult to get the children to do two-thirds of my work."

Principal Ferrier's work is the fact that he makes the best use of the resources of the school. By means of a government grant, by means of the heating system, he has cut the expenses of the school down to $1,000. He uses pupil labor, under proper supervision, to keep the premises in proper repair. Just now the rooms are being painted, and added beauty to the brightness of the rooms. All the practical work, cooking, washing, mending, making of garments is done by the pupils, who receive the best kind of teaching. The school has a constant supply of all kinds of goods on hand, even in times of great and unfavorable times. The pupils are taught order and system in their work, and apparently with something like military exactness.

Much is said of the need of agricultural schools for Indians, but the establishment of an agricultural college is not likely to be carried out in the near future; but it will, according to present appearance, be accomplished. The country has so complete an equipment for teaching agriculture that it is practicable to go young people, as it has for the training of young Indians.
Sir,

I am in receipt of your letter of the 26th ultimo, informing me that the Department has decided that it cannot see its way clear to acquire the land applied for by Rev. Dr. Sutherland on behalf of the Brandon Industrial School, and also asking for my report on the application of the Principal of said School that the number of pupils be raised from 100 to 125.

I visited the Brandon School last week to introduce the new Inspector for that district, Mr. Marlatt, and see the present state of the institution myself. I was much pleased with the condition of the school buildings; the ventilation is admirable, and the dormitories sufficiently large to accommodate 25 more pupils. If the full number of 125 were in the school there might perhaps be a little overcrowding in the dining room; but the class-rooms seem large enough for the desired increase. The Deputy Superintendent General:

In reply to the enquiries made in your memorandum of today with reference to the Brandon Industrial School I beg to say that there is nothing on file to show that the Principal of this school secures pupils by paying a bonus to the parents for allowing them to be placed there. He may, however, make some present by way of clothing or otherwise to induce them to part with their children, as it is said to be pretty generally the practice in the West to fill up the schools by this means. The denominational schools have clothing sent them, and I have learned from outside sources that they use it for this purpose, as the Indians will not give up their children voluntarily.

The Brandon Industrial School is one of the best managed institutions of this class in the Dominion, and the pupils have an excellent opportunity of acquiring a practical knowledge of general farming, but, as nearly all the pupils in this school are recruited from the country surrounding the northern end of Lake Winnipeg, which is not adapted for farming, they are not in a position to utilize the instruction they have received in agriculture when they return to their reserves. I have pointed this out in several previous memorandums on this school, and if the colony system for ex-pupils is to be followed, there are no ex-pupils so much in
need of segregation in an agricultural district as those from the Brandon school.

In this connection I beg to refer to my memorandum of December, 1902, in which I referred to a clipping from the Winnipeg Free Press of October 3, of that year, which contained the impressions gathered by visitors of the Methodist General Board of Missions during their meeting at Brandon on the Brandon Industrial School, the gist of which was that the industrial education given the Indian children has sometimes been mis-directed. The article says—"An Indian boy is not helped forward by acquiring a knowledge of printing instead of an expert use of the gun; or a girl by being taught to use a typewriter rather than to make moccasins, if the forests of the remote north are to be their permanent home. To know how to catch fish is more valuable knowledge than how to make a horse-shoe in a country where there never have been, and probably never will be, horses. To learn farming will be largely a loss of time if one is to live where there is no land that can be cultivated".

The Deputy Superintendent General,

Mr. Ferrier, Principal of the Brandon Industrial School, asks for permission to recruit from Ontario. He explains the situation very clearly in his letter of the 13th inst., and I see no reason why he should be restricted in recruiting pupils to Manitoba.

The pupils he has obtained come from the upper end of Lake Manitoba, and while at the school are thoroughly instructed in farming, but they have no opportunity to follow farming when they return to their reserves.

Mr. Ferrier asks permission to recruit from Western Ontario. The Methodists have a school under their control at Muncey, and have always an overflow of applicants, and I can see no objection to Mr. Ferrier being allowed to take the surplus, on the distinct understanding that the Department shall not be called upon to pay for their transport. The estimates for this school provide for 115 pupils at a per capita grant of $120, and the last return showed that they had only 93 enrolled, with an average attendance of 90, which would leave vacancies for 25.

The Brandon school affords one of the best agricultural trainings obtainable in the West, and I am fully convinced that it would be to the advantage of the Indian children of Western Ontario to receive a course of instruction at this school. There would be no inducements for them to desert, and when they left the school they would be in a position to make good settlers. The Brandon school is
on a par with the Experimental farm, which adjoins it,
and I know of no institution where better work is done.
Mr. Ferrier has managed to carry on his school successfully
with the per capita grant allowed him, and I think the
Department would be quite justified in allowing him to
recruit from Ontario to the extent of the vacancies at
present in the school, on the condition that no extra
expense is entailed to the Department.

Martin Benson

Rev. Sir:

In reply to your verbal enquiry for information as to the conditions upon which Indian children may be admitted to industrial and boarding schools I beg to say that the rule of the Department as embodied in the regulations respecting the education of Indian children is as follows:

"Nevertheless anything in these regulations contained no Protestant child shall be placed in a Roman Catholic school or in a school conducted under Roman Catholic auspices. And no Roman Catholic child shall be placed in a Protestant school or in a school conducted under Protestant auspices."

This regulation is absolutely just and places Roman Catholics and Protestants precisely upon the same footing. If, however, the parents of children so placed in either a Protestant or a Roman Catholic school have changed their religion, which it is quite competent for them to do, then upon evidence of such fact being brought to the Department an order will be made for the discharge of their children, that they may be transferred to a school conducted by the denomination to which the parents belong, should the parents so desire and if there are vacancies.
