A reply to the communication from the Department of Indian Affairs, addressed to Dr. Sutherland bearing date of May 12, 1910.

This letter suggests six propositions that need careful consideration.

1. Upon whom rests the responsibility for the policy which has been adopted for the management of the Brandon Institute during the past four years.

2. The Department assumes that they are paying the salary of Mr. Ferrier as Principal of the Institute, and also for his services as Superintendent of Indian Schools and Hospitals from the funds supplied by the Government for the maintenance of the Brandon School, and that the Church is hardly justified in accepting of the same.

3. That the salary paid to the Assistant Principal is insufficient, and not even fair when compared with the salary of the Principal.

4. That the Assistant is left with the sole responsibility of the Institute during the absence of the Principal.

5. The appointment of a Principal who can give all his time to the work of the Institute.

6. "That the general usefulness of the Institute suffers from the present arrangement."

We will deal with each of these propositions, and in the order in which they are named.

FIRST PROPOSITION.

Upon whom is the responsibility for the policy adopted for the management of the Brandon Institute during the past four years?
When this appointment of Superintendent of Indian Schools and Hospitals was made Dr. Sutherland notified the Principal of the Brandon School and asked him to come East and go with him to Ottawa. This appointment was discussed with the Secretary of the Department from a two-fold point of view. (1) To receive the sanction of the Department and its co-operation with the duties of this new office which was agreeably assented to. (2) To make provision for the future management of the Brandon School and the policy that has been pursued for the past four years was suggested by the Secretary of the Department. In support of this suggestion it was urged,

(a) That the Brandon School had become their Bamer Institute and that they were not willing that the Principal who had brought it to such a satisfactory condition should give up his control of it.

(b) That the experience of seven years would be of such a value, that it would not be necessary for the Principal to spend all his time in Brandon providing he could secure a good assistant.

(c) That there would be a vast amount of information gathered by visiting and inspecting other Institutes which could be incorporated into the management of the Brandon Institute, and thus make a model Institution for the education of the Indian boy and girl.

All of which was agreed to by Dr. Sutherland.

It will thus be seen that the Department is a partner to the policy adopted for the management of the Brandon Institute for the past four years.

SECOND PROPOSITION.

The assumption that the Department pays the salary of Mr. Ferrier as Principal of the Brandon Institute, and also for his services as Superintendent of Indian Schools and Hospitals, and that this salary is taken from the funds of the Brandon Institute, a mode of procedure that cannot be justified.
If this were a fact and not a mere assumption, it would not be hard to justify such a course of action.

The Indians are wards of the Government, and all the work of educating them should be paid for by the Government. The work of the Principal of the Brandon School and also that of the Superintendent of Indian Schools and Hospitals is all in the interests of the education and welfare of the Indians. The Methodist Church agrees to run these Institutes and Hospitals for a certain per capita grant. Has she not the right to use the money thus earned to pay the salary of the agents she employs to carry out the terms of the contract? From this point of view the practice and policy of the Methodist Church need no justification.

Dealing with this particular proposition, what are the facts in the case?

The cost of the Brandon Institute for the past four years, for maintenance, not including the products of the farm and garden, nor any grant from the Government for the buildings and plant, is as follows:

| Year ending June 30 | Net Cost | Gov't. Grant. | Paid by Church |
|---------------------|----------|---------------|----------------|
| 1907                | 12,500   | 1C,839        | 1161           |
| 1908                | 12,000   | 1C,256        | 1744           |
| 1909                | 13,500   | 1C,323        | 3117           |
| 1910                | 13,500   | 11,000        | 2500           |
| TOTAL               | 51,000   | 42,478        | 8522           |

The total received by the Principal for salary during the four years was $5,625. It will be seen from this that the Church has paid the salary in full and also contributed $2,897 toward the maintenance of the Institute during the four years, an average of $724 per year.

In the presence of these facts it is very clear that instead of the Government paying the salary of Mr. Ferrier, they have his services as the Principal of the Brandon Institute free.
In this connection it might be well to state that the Board has voted $12,000 per year for the Brandon Institute.

During the last two years the Executive has supplemented this by a vote of $1,500. The full amount of Mr. Ferrier's salary, and this should be so reported in our Annual Report and not charged up to the maintenance of the Brandon Institute. Had this mode of procedure been adopted, the Inspector's report would not have been misleading to the Department, and thus it would have saved the Department from the humiliating position of assuming that they were paying the salary in full, and charging the Methodist Church with adopting a policy that she could not justify.

THIRD PROPOSITION.

That the salary paid to the Vice Principal is insufficient, and not even fair when compared with that of the Principal.

The Conference of 1907 gave the Institute a young man who had been ordained one year. He was married. The Institute provided him with a furnished house, fuel, provisions from the farm and garden, the keep of his horse, and $600 in cash.

The total received was equal to about $850 and a furnished house.

The Conference of 1906 stationed the Rev. H.B. Allison, the Secretary of the Conference. This appointment was made in view of Mr. Allison becoming the Principal if circumstances warranted it, and if such would be in the interests of the Institute. The salary he received was $800, a furnished house, with fuel, light, milk, vegetables, fruits and horse-keep. This was more than the Principal received the first year he was in charge of the School. If Mr. Allison stayed for another year the understanding was that he should receive $1000.
The Conference of 1909 gave a young married man who had travelled one year under a Chairman but had not been received as a probationer. His wife was to have taught one of the classes; both were to live in the main building (which means board, washing and necessary medical attendance), and receive $600. His wife was unable to teach for more than a month, and he received at the rate of $500 per annum for his services.

There were special reasons why each of these men did not stay longer than one year, and if necessary these reasons can be given. In the meantime it may be sufficient to say that in neither case was the question of salary among the reasons. Nor was there any lack of harmony between the Principal and these men.

From these facts the Executive will be able to decide whether these men were dealt fairly with as far as salary is concerned.

FOURTH PROPOSITION.

That the Assistant Principal is left with the sole responsibility of the Institute during the absence of the Principal.

There are certain duties that have always been performed by the Principal, such as, the laying out of the farm and garden for crop and improvements, the securing of recruits, which requires a trip over the Southern part of the Lake Winnipeg District each year, the keeping of all books and accounts, and the general oversight that gives unity and keeps harmony within the Institution.

If the engineer leaves his engine room for a short time, it is hardly correct to say that the engine has the sole responsibility of running the machinery.
The Principal has spent eleven of the best years of his life in this class of work, and it does not now require all his time to run one institute.

When at home his duties as Superintendent of Schools and Hospitals have usually been attended to by giving an hour from 6 to 7 a.m., and from one to three hours after 8 p.m. in office work; and the rest of the day is largely devoted to the work of the Institute. He has never made any complaint about the amount of work he has been given to do on the one hand, nor has he on the other turned over the sole responsibility of the Brandon Institute upon his assistant.

FIFTH PROPOSITION.

The appointment of a Principal who can give all his time to the work of the Institute.

The Present Principal never sought this position nor any other that the Methodist Church has seen fit to honor him with. And for the first two or three years he gave all his time, and worked long days in order to master all the details of every department of this Institute. But during the last eight years and more, particularly during the last four years, he has been doing a vast amount of work over and above the management of this one school. As an illustration of this during the year 1909 he visited all our Institutes, Boarding Schools, Hospitals (except Hazelton) most of our Day Schools, and a large number of our Indian Reserves. This was done to glean information and to get a grip of our Indian Work. To do this it was necessary to travel 36,000 miles, and to spend about one-half of his time away from home. But such extensive visiting and travelling is not a necessity every year, and consequently even more time can be
given to the work of this particular Institute. However what he has done for the last four years he can continue to do so long as he enjoys the same good health and strength. He is not of the opinion that this Institute is degenerating in its usefulness and efficiency, and he would like action postponed until all the facts are before the Executive and the Department.

SIXTH PROPOSITION.

"That the general usefulness of the Institution suffers from this arrangement."

This ought to have some particular proof. A few questions might be asked, and in order to answer them some proof may be arrived at, or sufficient information to prove that there is no foundation for the statement.

Are the buildings degenerating in usefulness, and in their general appearance? Is the main building not kept well-heated, ventilated, clean, and thoroughly sanitary?

Are the live stock depreciating in value? Are they not in good condition? Is the farm and garden not well worked and made profitable as a training school for boys, and also as an asset in running the Institution?

Are any members of the staff over-worked, or under-paid? Are any of them complaining because of the treatment they receive?

Is the business of the School not well conducted? Are there any debts to pay? Are any of the merchants finding fault for not being promptly, and regularly paid? Is the Bank account over-drawn? Or, has the Department been called upon to pay any deficits for
maintenance, or to pay the salary of the Principal, or have they any similar school that is run as economically, and have they one they would like to hold up as an object lesson for the management of the Brandon Institute to copy after?

Are the children not well fed with good wholesome food, and clothed with good warm comfortable clothing? Are they not properly treated by the Principal and all other members of the staff? Are any of their parents or guardians complaining of the care, welfare, education and oversight given to the pupils? Is the order and discipline of the school or the moral and religious tone degenerating?

The Principal would like the most thorough investigation into all matters suggested by the above questions, and into any other matters that will reveal the facts regarding the general usefulness and efficiency of the Institute. He requests that a commission be appointed by the Executive to make this investigation.

All of which is respectfully submitted.

(Signed) T. FERRIER.

Dear Sir,

Replying to yours of June 18th re the engaging of a nurse, we have had a nurse now for two months. You will see from the Quarterly Report that the three children spoken of as seriously afflicted with tuberculosis have died.

About a year ago a boy was brought into the school with some affliction of skin trouble. It was not on his hands or face and very little on his body, and not much was thought of it. In fact, I knew nothing whatever about it and when first discovered the Doctor thought it was simply a rash that would pass away. However, we have discovered that since the spring of the year it has infected quite a number of pupils. This appears not on the hands or the face or any parts of the body exposed to the air, but is very troublesome now in the warm weather. I have had a careful examination of all the children and we have been giving them special treatment by the nurse under the Doctor's orders. These children who have been afflicted have greatly improved during the past month. It is very essential that we continue the services of the nurse for at least a couple of months longer, in order that all these cases may be carefully
treated, and the whole thing stamped out. I trust the Department will sanction the retaining of the nurse for at least two or three months longer.

Yours obediently,
